进一步阅读的建议

SUGGESTIONS FOR FURTHER READING

  • 约翰·D·卡普托，“存在的问题与先验现象学：对海德格尔与胡塞尔关系的思考。” 《现象学研究》 7(1)，1977年，第84-105页。
  • John D. Caputo, “The question of being and transcendental phenomenology: Reflections on Heidegger’s relationship to Husserl.” Research in Phenomenology 7(1), 1977, 84–105.
  • 史蒂文·克罗威尔，《海德格尔与胡塞尔：哲学的实质与方法》。载HL·德雷福斯和MA·拉索尔编，《海德格尔指南》 （第49-64页）。牛津：布莱克威尔出版社，2005年。
  • Steven Crowell, “Heidegger and Husserl: The matter and method of philosophy.” In H.L. Dreyfus and M.A. Wrathall (eds.), A Companion to Heidegger (pp. 49–64). Oxford: Blackwell, 2005.
  • Sara Heinämaa、Mirja Hartimo 和 Timo Miettinen（编辑），《现象学与先验》。伦敦：劳特利奇，2014 年。
  • Sara Heinämaa, Mirja Hartimo, and Timo Miettinen (eds.), Phenomenology and the Transcendental. London: Routledge, 2014.
  • 威廉·J·伦科夫斯基，“胡塞尔的‘epoche’是什么？胡塞尔语境中的哲学开端问题。” 《人与世界》 11(3–4)，1978年，第299–323页。
  • William J. Lenkowski, “What is Husserl’s epoche? The problem of beginning of philosophy in a Husserlian context.” Man and World 11(3–4), 1978, 299–323.

4科学与生活世界

4 SCIENCE AND THE LIFEWORLD

DOI：10.4324/9781003350682-6

DOI: 10.4324/9781003350682-6

对许多现象学家来说，现象学的任务并非描述经验和事实的特殊性，而是探究表征我们经验的本质结构、它们的相关因素以及两者之间的联系。作为哲学家，我们关注的并非主要偶然的特征和属性，而是必然和不变的特征和属性。我们关心的并非对一角硬币和一分硬币的感知有何差异，也不是对红酒和白酒的欲望有何差异；相反，我们关注的是感知或欲望的普遍特征。对一角硬币和一分硬币的感知在某些方面有所不同，但它们也有一些共同之处，即使这两种行为都成为感知行为而非想象或回忆行为的原因，而这些特征正是我们分析的目标。但我们如何做到这一点呢？我们如何才能洞察特定领域的本质结构？

For many phenomenologists, the task of phenomenology is not to describe empirical and factual particularities, but to investigate the essential structures characterising our experiences, their correlates, and the connection between the two. As philosophers, our concern is not primarily with accidental features and properties, but with necessary and invariant ones. We are not concerned with the difference between the perception of a dime and a penny, or the difference between the desire for red wine and white wine; rather, our concern is with what characterises perception or desire in general. The perception of the dime and the perception of the penny differ in some respects, but they also have something in common, namely that which makes both acts perceptual acts rather than acts of imagination or recollection, and those features are what our analysis should aim to disclose. But how do we do that? How can we obtain insights into the essential structures of a given domain?

在给出答案之前，我先强调一下，我们区分偶然和偶然特征与更本质和必要的特征的能力，不仅是哲学和科学的核心，也是我们在日常生活中不断运用的能力。例如，考虑一下购买新牙刷的任务。当你站在药店里，看着市面上有各种各样的牙刷型号，即使颜色和尺寸略有不同，我们也能立即识别出它们是不同类型的牙刷。我们认为颜色的变化与牙刷本身的本质是偶然的。同样，在寻找一本特定的书时，即使有人移动了它，它现在位于与之前不同的空间位置，我也能轻松地重新识别它。我立即意识到，它的空间位置与它的身份是偶然的，而且它不会仅仅因为被移动而改变其性质。

Before providing an answer, let me just emphasise that our ability to discriminate accidental and contingent features from more essential and necessary ones is an ability that is not only central to philosophy and science, but also one that we constantly and unproblematically employ in daily life. Consider, for example, the task of buying a new toothbrush. When standing in the pharmacy and looking at the diverse models on offer, we immediately recognise them as being different types of toothbrushes, even if they differ somewhat in colour and size. We see variations in colour as being accidental to that which makes a toothbrush a toothbrush. Likewise, when looking for a specific book, I do not have a problem re-identifying it, even if somebody moved it, and it is now located at a different point in space than before. I immediately recognise that its spatial location is accidental to its identity, and that it does not change nature simply by being moved.

本质主义

ESSENTIALISM

胡塞尔在探索本质结构时使用的工具之一是所谓的本质变异或本质还原。其基本思想是从给定的事物出发，然后运用我们的想象力。通过改变我们所研究的对象，通过将其想象成与实际情况不同的事物，我们可以慢慢地剥离其偶然属性，从而获得某些属性或特征，这些属性或特征一旦改变，研究对象就不再是它原本所属的对象。如果我们再次思考这本书，我可能会改变封面的颜色和设计；我可以增加或减少它的页数；我可以改变它的大小和重量等等。在进行这项练习时，我既依赖于我以往的书籍经验，也依赖于我的想象力。最终的结果是界定出一组属于这本书本身的属性，如果这些属性被改变，这本书就不再是一本书了。因此，想象的变化可以帮助我们揭示构成物体本质的不变结构。1

One of the tools employed by Husserl in his search for essential structures is what is known as the eidetic variation or eidetic reduction. The basic idea here is to take our point of departure in what is given to us, and then to use our imagination. By varying that which we are investigating, by imagining it as being different from how it actually is, we can slowly strip away its accidental properties, and thereby reach certain properties or features that cannot be changed without the object of investigation thereby also ceasing to be the kind of object it is. If we again consider the book, I might change the colour and design of the cover; I can add or subtract its number of pages; I can change its size and weight, etc. In performing this exercise, I am relying on both my previous experience of books and on the power of my imagination. The end result is the delimitation of a certain set of properties that belong to the book as such, and which, if changed, would make the book cease being a book. The imaginative variation can, consequently, help us disclose the invariant structures that make up the essence of the object.1

尽管胡塞尔有时会将所讨论的过程称为一种将产生某种本质直觉（Wesens - schau）的过程，但重要的是不要误解他的主张。首先，​​胡塞尔并不是说现象学家能够获得某种神秘而绝对正确的洞察力来源。本质变异可以被看作是一种由想象力引导或辅助的概念分析，它的目标与经验或实验工作截然不同，它无法取代经验或实验工作。它是一个要求高、开放的过程，其结果在大多数情况下是可以反驳的。简而言之，并不存在绝对正确的主张。相反，洞察力总是具有某种暂时性，某种预设性，并且必然会根据新证据对未来进行修改。2其次，胡塞尔有时会将他所谓的精确本质与形态本质区分开来。3尽管我们在纯数学和其他精确科学中能够非常精确地定义事物，但人文和社会科学所研究的大多数实体都具有本质的模糊性，它们具有形态的本质，而我们对这些实体的分类和描述本质上是近似的。试图将我们在几何学中发现的精确性和精确性强加到日常生活世界中的事物上，就是对后者的破坏。最后，当谈到现象学的任务时，胡塞尔当然不认为它关心的是揭示所谓的本质结构，比如婚姻、选举、单簧管或橡树。相反，胡塞尔是在更高的普遍性层面上探讨更为根本的主题。什么是……的普遍结构？意向性、具体化、时间性？感知与想象的区别是什么？物理对象本身有何特征？它与数学实体或心理过程有何区别？

Although Husserl sometimes talks of the process in question as one that will result in a kind of eidetic or essential intuition (Wesens-schau), it is important not to misunderstand his claims. First of all, Husserl is not suggesting that phenomenologists have access to some mysterious and infallible source of insight. The eidetic variation can be seen as a kind of imaginatively guided or aided conceptual analysis and has a quite different aim than empirical or experimental work, which it cannot replace. It is a demanding and open-ended process, and the results are in most cases defeasible. There is, in short, no claim to infallibility. Rather, the insights always possess a certain provisionality, a certain presumptiveness, and necessarily remain open for future modifications in the light of new evidence.2 Secondly, Husserl sometimes distinguishes what he calls exact essences from morphological essences.3 Whereas we in pure mathematics and other exact sciences are able to define matters with great precision, most of the entities studied by the human and social sciences are characterised by an essential vagueness, they possess morphological essences, and our classification and description of these entities are, by nature, approximative. To seek to impose the same exactness and precision that we find in geometry to matters in the world of everyday life is to do violence to the latter. Finally, when it comes to the task of phenomenology, Husserl certainly didn’t see it as being concerned with disclosing the alleged essential structure of, say, marriages, elections, clarinets, or oak trees. Rather, Husserl was pursuing far more fundamental topics at a much higher level of generality. What are the general structures of intentionality, of embodiment, of temporality? What distinguishes perception from imagination? What characterises a physical object as such and how is it distinct from a mathematical entity or a psychological process?

或许有必要将胡塞尔对不变和普遍结构存在的承诺与两种截然不同的立场区分开来。一方面，胡塞尔的本质主义类型不应与许多种族、后殖民和女性主义研究学者所批评的那种（社会-生物学）本质主义混为一谈，他们认为，种族、民族、性别等等是固定的、固有的、非历史性的决定因素。在这种观点下，身为父亲、丹麦人或犹太人，就意味着拥有某些固定不变的属性，这些属性在各个时代都是所有父亲、丹麦人和犹太人所共有的。相比之下，正如我们将在接下来的章节中看到的那样，胡塞尔非常清楚，这类概念在很大程度上受历史和文化的影响。

It might be helpful to distinguish Husserl’s commitment to the existence of invariant and universal structures from two alternative and quite opposed positions. On the one hand, Husserl’s type of essentialism should not be conflated with the kind of (socio-biological) essentialism criticised by many scholars in racial, postcolonial, and feminist studies according to which race, ethnicity, gender, etc. are fixed, inherent, and ahistorical determinations. In such a view, being, say, a father, or a Dane, or a Jew is to possess certain fixed and unchanging properties that are common to all fathers, Danes, and Jews at all times. By contrast, as we shall also see in the following chapters, Husserl was well aware of how much notions like these are subject to historical and cultural changes.

另一方面，胡塞尔的观点也必须与一些社会建构主义者所信奉的相对主义进行对比。例如，林肯和古巴在其著作《建构主义信条》中指出，相对主义是建构主义的基本本体论预设，即客观性是一种幻想，人文科学所研究的实体并不“真正”存在，因为它们纯粹是传统的，只存在于思考的人的头脑中。4忽视这种观点与胡塞尔和其他现象学家所持立场之间的关键区别将是一个重大错误。

On the other hand, Husserl’s view must also be contrasted with the relativism espoused by some social constructivists. In their book The Constructivist Credo, Lincoln and Guba, for instance, argue that relativism is the basic ontological presupposition of constructivism, that objectivity is a chimera, and that the entities studied by the human sciences do not “really” exist, since they are purely conventional and only exist in the minds of the persons contemplating them.4 To miss out on the crucial differences between a view like this and the position(s) espoused by Husserl and other phenomenologists would be a major mistake.

鉴于某种形式的本质主义在科学和（哲学史）中都广泛存在，重要的是不要将对本质结构的提及视为现象学哲学的独有特征。不应将本质变异与先验还原等同起来。事实上，优先考虑前者而忽视后者将是一个极其严重的错误。

Given how widespread some form of essentialism has been in both science and (the history of) philosophy, it is important not to consider the reference to essential structures as distinctive of phenomenological philosophy. One should not equate the eidetic variation with the transcendental reduction. In fact, it would be a particularly egregious mistake to prioritise the former at the expense of the latter.

我们在前面的章节中已经看到，现象学家想要转变回归事物本身。这句口号表明，我们的研究应该是批判性的、非教条的，应该远离形而上学的思辨。研究应该以实际所见为指导，而不是以我们根据理论承诺所期望发现的东西为指导。我们的方法应该由手头的研究主题决定，而不是由对特定科学理想的崇敬决定。正如海德格尔在《什么是形而上学》中所说，将科学的严谨性与数学的精确性等同起来是错误的。5我们不应该简单地认为，任何不能用数学精确性分析的领域就没有那么价值，甚至没有那么真实。

We have in earlier chapters seen how phenomenologists want to turn to the things themselves. The slogan indicates that our investigation should be critical and undogmatic and stay away from metaphysical speculations. It should be guided by what is actually given, rather than by what we expect to find given our theoretical commitments. Our method should be dictated by the subject matter at hand, rather than by veneration for a specific scientific ideal. As Heidegger remarks in What is Metaphysics, it is a mistake to equate scientific rigour with mathematical precision.5 We should not simply assume that any domain that cannot be analysed with mathematical exactitude is less valuable or even less real.

类似的想法也可以在胡塞尔的著作《形式逻辑与先验逻辑》中找到。胡塞尔在其著作《形式逻辑与先验逻辑》中警告人们，切勿被精确科学的方法论和理想所迷惑，仿佛它们构成了衡量真假的绝对规范。6我们不应让预先设定的理论决定我们能够体验什么，而应让经验对象引导我们的理论。我们应该让现象说话：

Similar ideas can be found in Husserl, who, in the work Formal and Transcendental Logic, warns against the danger of letting oneself be dazzled by the methodology and ideals of the exact sciences, as if they constituted the absolute norms for what counts as true and real.6 Rather than letting our predetermined theories decide what we can experience, we should let our theories be guided by the object of experience. We should let the phenomena speak:

真正的方法是遵循事物的本质，而不是我们的偏见和先入之见。7

我们需要的不是坚持亲眼所见，而是不要在偏见的压力下解释所见之事。8

the true method follows the nature of the things to be investigated and not our prejudices and preconceptions.7

what is needed is not the insistence that one see with his own eyes; rather it is that he not explain away under the pressure of prejudice what has been seen.8

正如胡塞尔所指出的，科学家们或许会采用比市场卖家更精确的测量方法，但这种精确度也有其自身的局限性。事实上，它对交易者来说用处不大。如果你如果你想卖一公斤橙子，你不想也不需要用微克来衡量重量。什么是充分、恰当和足够精确的衡量标准取决于具体情况，无法用绝对的术语来定义。9

As Husserl points out, the scientists might well employ more exact measurements than the market sellers, but this precision also has its own limitations. In fact, it is not of much use to the trader. If you want to sell a kilogram of oranges, you do not want to and do not need to measure the weight in micrograms. What is sufficient and appropriate and precise enough depends on the concrete context and cannot be defined in absolute terms.9

但这些格言难道不是毫无争议的琐碎之事吗？并非如此。在现象学看来，现实是复杂的，由众多不同的本体论领域组成（无论是理念领域、自然领域还是文化领域等等）。任何对这些领域或领域的研究都应尊重其独特性和鲜明特征，并采用适合该领域的方法。10因此，现象学一直直言不讳地批评各种不同的、部分重叠的立场，包括还原论，消除主义，以及自然主义。

But are these maxims not uncontroversial trivialities? Not quite. In the phenomenological view, reality is complex and consists of a multitude of different ontological regions (be it the realm of idealities, of nature, of culture, etc.). Any investigation of these realms or regions should respect their peculiarities and distinct features and employ methods that are appropriate for the domain in question.10 As a consequence, phenomenology has been outspoken in its criticism of a variety of different, partially overlapping, positions, including reductionism, eliminativism, and naturalism.

减少或消除

REDUCE OR ELIMINATE

科学还原论受到各种方法论原则的推动，其中包括奥卡姆剃刀：不要假设存在超出严格必要范围的对象类型（或本体论领域）。如果我们要在几种理论（每种理论都处理现实的自身部分）和一种理论（该理论能够通过将较复杂的部分简化为较简单的部分来系统地解释现实的不同部分）之间做出选择，我们应该选择后者。这不仅是因为越来越多的统一性、系统性和简单性在理论上令人满意，还因为所讨论的简化应该具有解释力。如果某一范围的属性可以简化为另一范围的属性，则前者可以用后者来解释。一个典型的例子是试图通过诉诸对象的微观属性（即其分子组成）来解释对象的宏观属性（例如温度、透明度、溶解度或弹性）。因此，一个常见的假设是：如果我们想要回答“x 是什么？”这个问题，那么这个问题就必须重新表述为“如何将 x 简化为物理学、化学或神经生理学能够理解的东西？”此外，还有一种假设是，除非能够给出这样的答案，除非所考虑的现象能够被简化，否则它就不可能是真实的。这种观点的表述可以在 Jerry福多尔：“很难想象一个人如何成为一个现实主义者意向性，但在某种程度上，也不是一种还原论者。[...]如果关于性是真实的，那么它一定是别的东西”。11因此，假设只有对意识进行还原性的解释，才能让我们真正洞察意识的本质，并且只有当这种还原性的解释成为可能时，意识才是真实的。

Scientific reductionism is motivated by various methodological principles, including the one known as Ockham’s razor: Do not assume the existence of more types of objects (or ontological realms) than is strictly necessary. If we are to choose between several theories, each of which treats its own part of reality, and a single theory, which in a systematic fashion can explain different parts of reality by reducing the more complex parts to less complex parts, we should choose the latter. This is not only because an increasing amount of unity, systematicity, and simplicity is theoretically satisfying, but also because the reduction in question is supposed to possess explanatory power. If a certain range of properties can be reduced to another range of properties, the former can be explained by the latter. A classic example is the attempt to explain an object’s macro properties, such as temperature, transparency, solubility, or elasticity, by appeal to its micro properties, i.e., its molecular composition. A common assumption has, consequently, been that if we want an answer to the question “what is x?”, then the question has to be reformulated as “how can x be reduced to something that can be understood by physics, chemistry or neurophysiology?” In addition, there is the assumption that unless such an answer can be given, unless the phenomenon under consideration can be reduced, it cannot be real. A formulation of this view can be found in Jerry Fodor: “It’s hard to see [. . .] how one can be a Realist about intentionality without also being, to some extent or other, a Reductionist. [. . .] If aboutness is real, it must be really something else”.11 The assumption has, consequently, been that only a reductive account of, say, consciousness can offer us a real insight into the nature of consciousness, and that consciousness will only be real if such a reductive account is possible.

取消主义者与还原主义者有着许多相同的担忧。只有能够运用自然科学方法和原理解释的事物才算真实。但与还原主义者相反，取消主义者认为意识不能被还原为神经生理过程之类的概念。在她看来，这种还原是不可能的。但她并没有得出看似自然的结论——意识不可还原——而是得出了一个不同的结论，即意识并不存在。对于取消唯物主义者来说，我们关于“欲望、恐惧、感觉、喜悦、痛苦等等” 12之类的存在，这些信念只不过是一些理论假设，它们共同构成了一种原始的心理学理论。这种原始理论不符合当代科学的标准，它不是一个可信的心理学理论，因此必须被摒弃，就像过去人们摒弃炼金术和颅相学一样。简而言之，之所以不可能将意识简化为值得尊敬的自然属性，是因为前者并不存在；意识不是真实的，而是与独角兽和雪人一样虚构的。

The eliminativist shares many of the same concerns as the reductionist. Only that which can be accounted for using the methods and principles of the natural sciences count as real. But in contrast to the reductionist, the eliminativist argues that consciousness cannot be reduced to, say, neurophysiological processes. In her view, it is not possible to carry out this reduction. But rather than then drawing what would appear to be the natural conclusion – that consciousness is irreducible – she draws a different conclusion, namely that consciousness doesn’t exist. For the eliminative materialist, our beliefs that there exists something like “desire, fear, sensation, joy, pain, and so on”12 are nothing but theoretical assumptions that together constitute a primitive psychological theory. This primitive theory does not live up to the standards of contemporary science, it is not a credible psychological theory, and it therefore has to be rejected, just as one in the past has rejected, say, alchemy and phrenology. In short, the reason why it is impossible to reduce consciousness to respectable natural properties is because the former does not exist; consciousness is not real, but a fiction on a par with unicorns and yetis.

科学自然主义以其方法论和本体论的投入为特征。方法论的投入意味着，正确的程序和正确的论证类型，正是自然科学所发现和运用的。所有真正的问题都是自然科学问题，所有真正的知识都是通过自然科学手段获得的知识。引用伽利略的话——胡塞尔认为他是这种倾向的早期化身——是这样的：

Scientific naturalism is distinguished by methodological as well as ontological commitments. The methodological commitment amounts to the idea that the correct procedures and the right types of justification are those found in and employed by the natural sciences. All genuine questions are natural scientific questions, and all genuine knowledge is knowledge gained by natural scientific means. To quote Galileo, whom Husserl sees as an early personification of this tendency:

哲学写在宇宙这本宏大的书里，它始终展现在我们的眼前。但除非我们首先学会理解它的语言，并读懂构成它的字母，否则我们无法理解这本书。它用数学的语言写成，它的字符是三角形、圆形和其他几何图形，没有它们，人类就不可能理解其中任何一个词；没有这些，人就会在黑暗的迷宫中徘徊。13

philosophy is written in this grand book, the universe, which stands continually open to our gaze. But the book cannot be understood unless one first learns to comprehend the language and read the letters in which it is composed. it is written in the language of mathematics, and its characters are triangles, circles, and other geometric figures without which it is humanly impossible to understand a single word of it; without these, one wanders about in a dark labyrinth.13

从历史上看，类似的考量常常与本体论承诺相伴而生，根据这种承诺，现实仅由那些被（或可能被）自然科学所接受的实体、属性和结构构成。最初，这种主张认为，物体的形状、大小和重量，即那些可以用数学精度定量描述的特征，是客观属性，而物体的颜色、味道和气味则是主观现象，缺乏任何独立于心智的现实性。这种对主要属性和次要属性的经典区分，多年来已被激进化，并最终导致了一种观点：缺乏的不仅仅是物体外观的某些属性客观性，而是所有显现的事物。整个经验世界是一个主观的建构，一场清醒的梦，如果科学要揭示现实的真正本质，它就必须超越一切现象学上既定的事物。我们生活的世界，我们从经验中熟悉的世界，与我们所处的科学世界，只有后者才配得上称之为真实的。

Historically speaking, considerations like these have often been coupled with ontological commitments according to which reality consists only of those entities, properties, and structures that are (or could be) accepted by natural science. Initially, the claim was that the form, size, and weight of an object, i.e., those features which can be described quantitatively with mathematical precision, are objective properties, whereas the colour, taste, and smell of the object are subjective phenomena that lack any mind-independent reality. This classical distinction between the primary and secondary qualities has over the years been radicalised and eventually led to the idea that it is not merely certain properties of the appearing object that lack objectivity, but everything that appears. The entire world of experience is a subjective construct, a wakeful dream, and if science is to disclose the true nature of reality, it consequently has to move beyond everything phenomenologically given. The world we live in, the world we are familiar with from experience, is quite different from the world of science, and only the latter deserves to be called real.

这两个承诺合在一起就形成了一种观点，即每一个真理都是自然科学真理，并且一切存在的事物（包括与人类生活有关的一切，例如意识、意向性、意义、理性、规范性、价值观、文化、历史等）都必须用自然科学的方法进行研究，并且最终可以在解释和本体论上归结为自然科学事实。

Jointly, the two commitments amount to the view that every truth is a natural scientific truth, and that everything which exists (including everything pertaining to human life, such as consciousness, intentionality, meaning, rationality, normativity, values, culture, history, etc.) must be studied by the methods of natural science and are ultimately explanatorily and ontologically reducible to natural scientific facts.

我们正在应对的立场十分激进，这一点显而易见。如果“减少或消除”这一共同口号成立，那么社会科学和人文科学中的许多解释都将是伪解释，缺乏真正的科学价值。此外，社会科学和人文科学所研究的许多对象和现象的真实性也值得怀疑。想想金钱、邮票、交响乐、市政选举或战争等现象。很难想象如何能够充分解释目前正在乌克兰或加沙发生的战争，因为运用神经生理学、生物学或物理学原理来解释政治、文化、社会和经济现象。但如果这句口号是真的，我们就必须得出结论：严格来说，乌克兰或加沙从未发生过战争。但这难道不荒谬吗？这种结论难道不是在推翻这句口号吗？

That we are dealing with radical positions should be obvious. If the shared slogan “reduce or eliminate” is true, many of the explanations found in the social and human sciences will be pseudo-explanations with no real scientific value. In addition, the reality of many of the objects and phenomena that are investigated by the social and human sciences will also be questionable. Consider phenomena such as money, stamps, symphonies, municipal elections, or wars. It is hard to see how it should be possible to account adequately for the currently ongoing wars in Ukraine or Gaza as political, cultural, social, and economic phenomena by means of the principles of neurophysiology, biology, or physics. But if the slogan is true, we would have to conclude that, strictly speaking, there never were any wars in Ukraine or Gaza. But is this not absurd, and does this kind of conclusion not present us with a reductio ad absurdum of the slogan?

这生活世界

THE LIFEWORLD

在反思科学世界现状的过程中，现象学家经常强调生活世界的重要性。但生活世界是什么？声称要恢复生活世界的意义又是什么？

In the course of reflecting on the status of the world of science, phenomenologists have often emphasised the importance of the lifeworld. But what is the lifeworld, and what does it mean to claim that it has to be rehabilitated?

生活世界，毫不奇怪，就是我们赖以生存的世界。它并非一个由可量化的物理对象、化学化合物、亚原子粒子或神经回路组成的无价值世界。相反，它是一个包含桌子、书籍、灯具、咖啡杯、报纸、树木、公园、道路、云朵等等的世界，这些或多或少是我们熟悉的、有用的自然之物，我们能立即联想到它们有趣、易得、无关紧要、无用等等。我们是社会人，我们所栖居的世界也由我们遇到的其他人构成，例如亲戚、朋友、同事、竞争对手、员工、陌生人等等。生活世界是我们在日常生活中习以为常的世界，是我们都熟悉的前科学经验世界，它构成了我们日常行动和行为的基础。

The lifeworld is, unsurprisingly, the world we live in. This is not a value-free world of quantifiable physical objects, chemical compounds, subatomic particles, or neural circuits. Rather, it is a world that contains tables, books, lamps, coffee cups, newspapers, trees, parks, roads, clouds, etc., i.e., more or less familiar objects of use and nature that we immediately relate to as interesting, accessible, extraneous, useless, etc. We are social beings and the world we inhabit is also populated by other people we meet as relatives, friends, colleagues, competitors, employees, strangers, etc. The lifeworld is the world we take for granted in daily life, it is the prescientific world of experience which we are all acquainted with, and which forms the basis of our daily actions and behaviour.

我们主要了解和感到自在的世界不是一个独立于主体的现实，而是一个充满人类的、与主体相关的世界。意义。这个世界是由我们自身的身体属性和位置所构建的。我们感知事物时，会将其视为行动——杯子可以喝水，勺子可以吃东西，椅子可以坐下，树可以爬树——以及事物的左或右，触手可及或更远，可触及或不可触及。这也是一个由历史和文化塑造的世界，一个构成我们熟悉的世界。我们作为身体主体所锚定并融入的意义视野。

The world we primarily know and feel at home in is not a subject-independent reality, but a subject-relative world filled with human meaning. It is a world that is structured by references to our own bodily nature and location. We perceive things as affording actions – the cup affords drinking, the spoon eating, the chair sitting, the tree climbing – and as being to the left or right, as being within reach or further away, as accessible or inaccessible. It is also a historically and culturally shaped world, a world that constitutes the familiar horizon of meaning we as bodily subjects are anchored in and socialised into.

为什么这个世界需要被修复？因为生活世界已被科学遗忘和压制，而科学正是构成生活世界历史和体系的基础。即使是最精确、最抽象的科学理论借鉴了生活世界的前科学证据。在探寻客观知识的过程中，科学以其超越身体、感官和实践经验的能力为美德，但却常常忽视了这些经验在多大程度上赋予了科学以力量。毕竟，“物理学家按照物理方法探索并科学测定”的往往是人们感知到的日常事物，而非其他。14自然科学家也在研究天空中观测到的行星、饮用的水、欣赏到的花朵等等，并力求以尽可能准确和客观的方式确定它们的真实本质。然而，即使在科学研究的对象远离日常实践的情况下，在计划和设置实验时，在读取测量仪器读数时，在与其他科学家解释、比较和讨论结果时，共同的生活世界仍然在发挥作用。尽管科学理论的精确性和抽象性超越了具体的、直观给定的生活世界，但后者仍然是一个不变的参考来源。

Why does this world need to be rehabilitated? Because the life-world has been forgotten and repressed by science, whose historical and systematic foundation it constitutes. Even the most exact and abstract scientific theories draw on the prescientific evidence of the lifeworld. In its search for objective knowledge, science has made a virtue of its ability to move beyond and surpass bodily, sensuous, and pragmatic experience, but has frequently overlooked to what extent it is enabled by those very same experiences. After all, it is often the perceived everyday object, and none other, that the “physicist explores and scientifically determines following the method of physics”.14 It is the planetary bodies observed in the sky, the water drunk, the flower admired, etc. that the natural scientist is also investigating and whose true nature she seeks to determine in as exact and objective a manner as possible. Even in those cases, however, where the object of the scientific investigation is far removed from everyday practice, the shared lifeworld remains in play, when planning and setting up the experiments, when reading the measuring instruments, when interpreting, comparing, and discussing the results with other scientists. Even though scientific theories in their precision and abstraction supersede the concrete and intuitively given lifeworld, the latter remains a constant source of reference.

将生活世界与科学世界之间的关系视为一种静态关系是错误的。科学汲取生活世界的经验，同时也影响生活世界，并逐渐将其理论洞见吸收并融入生活世界。斯特拉瑟将生活世界比作肥沃的土壤。正如土壤能够滋养丰饶的植物，生活世界也能滋养理论知识。正如土壤的物理和化学性质会因其所促进的植物生长而改变一样，生活世界也会因其所构建的理论体系而改变和变化。15

It would be wrong to conceive of the relation between the life-world and the world of science as a static relation. Science draws on the lifeworld, but it also affects the lifeworld, and gradually its theoretical insights are absorbed by and integrated into the latter. Strasser has compared the lifeworld with fertile soil. Just as the soil might nourish a rich growth, the lifeworld can nourish theoretical knowledge. And just as the physical and chemical properties of the soil are modified by the plant growth it allows for, the lifeworld is modified and changed by the theoretical theories that it constitutes the foundation for.15

当现象学家强调生活世界的重要性时，这并非旨在批判科学。现象学并非要质疑科学的价值，也并非否认科学研究能够带来新的洞见并拓展我们对现实的理解。但现象学家确实拒绝接受自然科学能够对现实进行详尽阐述的观点。重要的是，这并不意味着现象学本身就与定量方法和研究对立。后者固然优秀，但仅限于处理定量问题时。对于现象学而言，关于某物是否真实的问题，并非取决于它是否能符合可量化科学的普罗克拉斯提斯之床。我们的经验世界有其自身的有效性和真实性标准，不必等待科学的认可。事实上，科学发现和日常经验不必相互矛盾。根据各自的标准，它们都可以是真实的。更一般地说，对于现象学家来说，经验世界和科学世界之间的区别不在于我们为之的世界和世界自在之间的区别，而在于世界呈现的两种方式之间的区别。科学世界不是一个自主的世界，不是一个在显性世界之后或之下的世界。相反，科学研究的世界与日常经验的世界——即显性现实——是同一个世界，但现在是用科学术语进行研究和探索的。能够呈现在我们面前的世界——无论是在感知中，在我们的日常关注中，还是在我们的科学分析中——才是唯一的真实世界。声称除了这个世界之外，还存在一个超越一切表象和一切经验证据的幕后世界，并将这个世界认定为真正的现实，这是所有现象学家都拒绝的做法。16 我们不应该将客观现实定义为自在存在的东西，不应该区分事物对于我们而言是怎样的，不应该区分事物对于我们而言是怎样的，不应该坚持认为对后者的探究才是真正重要的，我们应该正视这样一个事实：客观性是一种既涉及主观性又涉及主体间性。事实上，对胡塞尔来说，主体间性并非客观性的对立面，也并非构成科学知识的障碍和阻碍，而是一个必要的赋能条件。胡塞尔信奉一种世俗的客观性和实在性概念，从而摒弃了那种怀疑论认为，我们所看到的世界与完全不同的现实世界是相容的。事实上，对胡塞尔来说，客观性并非以独立于心灵的方式定义，而是与一种思想共同体。客观性是主体间互动过程的结果。它是我们在探究结束时能够达成一致的。

When phenomenologists highlight the significance of the life-world, this is not intended as a criticism of science. Phenomenology is not out to dispute the value of science and is not denying that scientific investigations can lead to new insights and expand our understanding of reality. But phenomenologists do reject the idea that natural science can provide an exhaustive account of reality. Importantly, this does not entail that phenomenology is, as such, opposed to quantitative methods and studies. The latter are excellent, but only when addressing quantitative questions. For phenomenology, the question of whether something is real or not, does not depend on whether it can fit the Procrustean bed of quantifiable science. Our world of experience has its own criteria of validity and truth and does not have to await the approval of science. Indeed, the findings of science and everyday experience do not have to contradict each other. They can both be true according to their own standards. More generally speaking, the difference between the world of experience and the world of science is for phenomenologists not a difference between the world for us and the world in itself, but a difference between two ways in which the world appears. The world of science is not an autonomous world, a world behind or below the manifest world. Rather, the world that science studies is the same world as that of everyday experience – namely, manifest reality – but now studied and explored in scientific terms. The world that can appear to us – be it in perception, in our daily concerns, or in our scientific analyses – is the only real world. To claim that in addition to this world there exists a world behind the scenes, which transcends every appearance and every experiential evidence, and to identify this world as the really real reality, is a move that is rejected by all phenomenologists.16 Rather than defining objective reality as what is there in itself, rather than distinguishing how things are for us from how they are simpliciter in order then to insist that the investigation of the latter is the truly important one, we should face up to the fact that objectivity is an accomplishment that involves both subjectivity and intersubjectivity. Indeed, rather than being the antipode of objectivity, rather than constituting an obstacle and hindrance to scientific knowledge, (inter)subjectivity is for Husserl a necessary enabling condition. Husserl embraces a this-worldly conception of objectivity and reality and thereby dismisses the kind of scepticism that would argue that the way the world appears to us is compatible with the real world being completely different. Indeed, for Husserl, objectivity is precisely not defined in terms of mind-independence, but rather in relation to a community of minds. Objectivity is the outcome of an intersubjective process. It is what we can agree upon at the end of inquiry.

只有那些自然科学已知（或能够）的实体和事实才是客观实在的观点，不仅通常未能恰当地触及和解决“实在性和客观性究竟是什么”这一哲学问题，而且这也是一种自我毁灭的事业，因为它未能充分解释那些使自然主义——作为对世界的一种特定态度和观点——首先是可能的。

The view that only those entities and facts that are (or can be) known by natural science are objectively real does not only typically fail to properly engage with and address the philosophical question of what precisely reality and objectivity amount to. It is also a self-undermining enterprise in that it fails to adequately account for those experiential and cognitive achievements that make naturalism – as a specific attitude to and perspective on the world – possible in the first place.

科学通常表现为试图客观地描述现实，即从第三人称视角。追求客观性当然值得称赞，但我们不应忘记，任何客观性、任何解释、理解和理论模型，都以第一人称视角为前提。意向性是其前提。从这个意义上讲，认为科学能够提供对现实的绝对解释，摆脱一切理论和经验视角的想法，是一种幻觉。科学是一种与世界的独特关系，是对自然态度的一种特殊的理论修正。这理论态度并非从天而降，而是有其自身的预设和起源。它是一种传统，一种文化形态。它是由一群体验主体共同体所共享的知识，并以观点或视角的三角关系为前提。这也是为什么通常将第一人称与第三人称叙述对立起来会产生误导。它让我们忘记了第三人称的科学叙述是由一个有意识的主体共同体完成和生成的。不存在纯粹的第三人称视角，正如不存在虚无缥缈的视角。当然，这并不是说不存在第三人称视角，而只是说这种视角恰恰是一种来自某个地方的视角。这是一种我们可以用来观察世界的观点。科学的根源在于生活世界，它借鉴了前科学领域的洞见，并由具身和嵌入的主体来执行。如果我们想要理解科学的表现和局限性，就必须研究认知主体所使用的意向性形式。如果没有意识主体来解释和讨论它们，仪表设置、计算机打印输出、X 光照片等等就毫无意义。因此，根据这种观点，意识本身非但不是阻碍或障碍，反而是客观性和追求科学知识的一个比显微镜和望远镜更为重要的先决条件。现象学的目的不是提供一种与人类相竞争的科学解释，而是通过详细分析人类所运用的意向性类型来阐明我们的科学实践、其合理性和成就。了解主体雇用。我们在进行科学研究时所采用的理论态度是否源于并改变了我们前理论的存在状态？

Science often presents itself as an attempt to describe reality objectively, i.e., from a third-person perspective. The search for objectivity is, of course, laudable, but we shouldn’t forget that any objectivity, any explanation, understanding, and theoretical modelling, presupposes first-person intentionality as its precondition. To that extent, the idea that science can deliver an absolute account of reality, one that is liberated from every theoretical and experiential perspective, is an illusion. Science is a distinct relation to the world, a particular theoretical modification of the natural attitude. This theoretical attitude did not fall down from the sky but has its own presuppositions and genesis. It is a tradition, a cultural formation. It is knowledge that is shared by a community of experiencing subjects and which presupposes a triangulation of points of view or perspectives. This is also why the usual opposition of first-person vs. third-person accounts is misleading. It makes us forget that third-person scientific accounts are accomplished and generated by a community of conscious subjects. There is no pure third-person perspective, just as there is no view from nowhere. This is, of course, not to say that there is no third-person perspective, but merely that such a perspective is, precisely, a perspective from somewhere. It is a view that we can adopt on the world. Science has its roots in the lifeworld, it draws on insights from the prescientific sphere, and is performed by embodied and embedded subjects. If we wish to comprehend the performance and limits of science, we must investigate the forms of intentionality that are employed by the cognising subjects. Without conscious subjects to interpret and discuss them, meter settings, computer printouts, x-ray pictures, and the like remain meaningless. Thus, according to this view, rather than being, as such, a hindrance or obstacle, consciousness turns out to be a far more important prerequisite for objectivity and the pursuit of scientific knowledge than, say, microscopes and telescopes. The aim of phenomenology is not to offer a competing scientific explanation of human beings, but to clarify our scientific practice, its rationality, and accomplishments, through a detailed analysis of the kinds of intentionality that the knowing subject(s) employ(s). How does the theoretical attitude that we employ when we conduct science arise out of and change our pre-theoretical being-in-the-world?

笔记

NOTES

  4. As a case in point, consider how the invention of digital books has led to a revised conception of what counts as a book.

  21. Fodor, J. (1987).心理语义学。马萨诸塞州剑桥：麻省理工学院出版社：97。
  22. Fodor, J. (1987). Psychosemantics. Cambridge, MA: MIT Press: 97.
  23. Churchland, PM (1988)。《物质与意识：当代心灵哲学导论》。修订版。马萨诸塞州剑桥：麻省理工学院出版社：44。
  24. Churchland, P.M. (1988). Matter and Consciousness: A Contemporary Introduction to the Philosophy of Mind. Revised edn. Cambridge, MA: MIT Press: 44.
  25. 伽利略， G. (1957)。伽利略的发现与观点。纽约：Anchor House：237–238。
  26. Galileo, G. (1957). Discoveries and Opinions of Galileo. New York, NY: Anchor House: 237–238.
  27. 胡塞尔， E. (1982)。《关于纯粹现象学和现象学哲学的理念》。第一卷。《纯粹现象学导论》，F. Kersten 译。海牙：Martinus Nijhoff：119。
  28. Husserl, E. (1982). Ideas Pertaining to a Pure Phenomenology and to a Phenomenological Philosophy. First Book. General Introduction to a Pure Phenomenology, trans. F. Kersten. The Hague: Martinus Nijhoff: 119.
  29. 斯特拉瑟， S. (1963)。现象学与人文科学：对新科学理想的贡献。宾夕法尼亚州匹兹堡：杜肯大学出版社：71。
  30. Strasser, S. (1963). Phenomenology and the Human Sciences: A Contribution to a New Scientific Ideal. Pittsburgh, PA: Duquesne University Press: 71.
  31. 例如，参见胡塞尔，E.（1982）。 《关于纯粹现象学和现象学哲学的理念。第一卷。《纯粹现象学概论》，F. Kersten译。海牙：Martinus Nijhoff出版社，122页。
  32. See, for instance, Husserl, E. (1982). Ideas Pertaining to a Pure Phenomenology and to a Phenomenological Philosophy. First Book. General Introduction to a Pure Phenomenology, trans. F. Kersten. The Hague: Martinus Nijhoff: 122.

进一步阅读的建议

SUGGESTIONS FOR FURTHER READING

  • Eran Dorfman，“生活世界的历史：从胡塞尔到梅洛-庞蒂。” 《今日哲学》 53(3)，2009，294–303。
  • Eran Dorfman, “History of the lifeworld: From Husserl to Merleau-Ponty.” Philosophy Today 53(3), 2009, 294–303.
  • 罗伯特·汉纳，“胡塞尔的危机与我们的危机。” 《国际哲学研究杂志》 22(5)，2014，752–770。
  • Robert Hanna, “Husserl’s crisis and our crisis.” International Journal of Philosophical Studies 22(5), 2014, 752–770.
  • 克劳斯·赫尔德，《胡塞尔的生活世界现象学》。载D.韦尔顿主编，《新胡塞尔：批判性读本》（第32-62页）。印第安纳州布卢明顿：印第安纳大学出版社，2003年。
  • Klaus Held, “Husserl’s phenomenology of the life-world.” In D. Welton (ed.), The New Husserl: A Critical Reader (pp. 32–62). Bloomington, IN: Indiana University Press, 2003.
  • 安东尼·斯坦博克，《家园与彼岸：胡塞尔之后的生成现象学》。伊利诺斯州埃文斯顿：西北大学出版社，1995年。
  • Anthony Steinbock, Home and Beyond: Generative Phenomenology after Husserl. Evanston, IL: Northwestern University Press, 1995.

5深入挖掘

5 DIGGING DEEPER

从表层到深层的现象学

From surface to depth phenomenology

DOI：10.4324/9781003350682-7

DOI: 10.4324/9781003350682-7

评价现象学发展的一种方式是将其视为胡塞尔早期著作中基本现象学分析的不断扩展、深化和复杂化。胡塞尔本人最终将他最初开展的现象学称为静态现象学。如果我们考察一些早期对感知的形成性分析，意向性以及感知与想象之间的关系，他们都研究意向性不考虑起源的相关性和历史性。对象的类型和意向性行为的类型都被认为是现成的。然而，胡塞尔后来意识到，意向性主体不仅仅是一个形式原则，构成，正如他所说，它并非“同一性的死极”，1同样的情况也适用于对象方面。胡塞尔继续考察理解模式是如何逐渐建立的，以及它们如何影响和促成后续经验。通过一个过程在沉淀的过程中，我们的经验在我们心中留下痕迹，从而有助于形成认知图式以及各种理解和期望，这些理解和期望会引导和激发后续的经验。某些类型的意向性（例如，前语言经验）决定了后期更复杂的意向性类型（例如，概念判断），并且胡塞尔承担了后来被他称为发生现象学的课题，旨在考察这些不同意向性形式的时间生成，并将客观性的高阶形式追溯到低阶形式。2然而，发生现象学的范围仍然局限于个体自我的体验生活。在其思想的最后阶段，胡塞尔涉足了所谓的生成现象学。3其焦点被拓展到考察传统和历史。前几代人的成就以何种方式在我们个人的经历中发挥作用？正如胡塞尔在20世纪20年代的一份手稿中所言，“我自己的一切，一部分源于我祖先的传统，一部分源于我同时代人的传统” 。4

One way to appraise the development of phenomenology is to see it as a continuous expansion, deepening, and complexification of the basic phenomenological analysis that we find in Husserl’s early work. Husserl himself eventually came to label the kind of phenomenology he initially had conducted as a static phenomenology. If we consider some of the early formative analyses of perceptual intentionality and of the relation between perception and imagination, they all studied the intentional correlation with no regard for genesis and historicity. The type of object and the type of intentional act were both considered readily available. Subsequently, however, Husserl came to realise that the subject of intentionality is not merely a formal principle of constitution, it is not, as he puts it, “a dead pole of identity”,1 and the same holds true on the object side. Husserl went on to examine how patterns of understanding are gradually established and how they come to influence and enable subsequent experiences. Through a process of sedimentation, our experiences leave their trace in us and thereby contribute to the formation of cognitive schemas and diverse forms of apprehension and expectations that guide and motivate subsequent experiences. Certain types of intentionality (prelinguistic experiences, for example) condition later and more complex types of intentionality (conceptual judgments, for instance), and Husserl took the task of what he eventually called genetic phenomenology to involve the examination of the temporal becoming of these different forms of intentionality, one that also traced higher-order forms of objectivity back to lower-order forms.2 The scope of genetic phenomenology remained restricted to the experiential life of an individual ego, however. In the last phase of his thinking, Husserl ventured into what has been called generative phenomenology.3 The focus was broadened to investigate the constitutive role of tradition and history. In what way are the accomplishments of previous generations operative in our individual experiences? As Husserl would put it in a manuscript from the twenties, “everything of my own is founded, in part through the tradition of my ancestors, in part through the tradition of my contemporaries”.4

生殖力与传统

GENERATIVITY AND TRADITION

这种发展在胡塞尔自己的著作中得到体现，就是通过更加关注具体化，时间性和社会性交织在一起。正如我们已经看到的，胡塞尔认为身体本质上参与了对空间对象的感知和互动。对他来说，世界是通过身体探索而呈现给我们的，而身体则在其对世界的探索中向我们揭示。胡塞尔很早就意识到时间性的重要性，并捍卫了这样的观点：只要忽视意向性行为和意向性对象的时间维度，对意向性的探究就将是不完整的。此外，胡塞尔是最早运用和讨论“时间”概念的哲学家之一。全面而系统地阐述了主体间性。他研究共情三十余年，最终宣称现象学必须从“自我学现象学”发展为“社会学现象学” 。5

One way this development is traced out in Husserl’s own writings is through an increased focus on how the topics of embodiment, temporality, and sociality are intertwined. As we have already seen, Husserl argued that the body is essentially involved in the perception of and interaction with spatial objects. For him, the world is given to us as bodily explored, and the body is revealed to us in its exploration of the world. Early on, Husserl also came to realise the importance of temporality, and defended the view that an investigation of intentionality will remain incomplete as long as one ignores the temporal dimension of the intentional acts and intentional objects. In addition, Husserl was one of the first philosophers to employ and discuss the notion of intersubjectivity in a comprehensive and systematic manner. He worked on empathy for more than three decades and would eventually declare that phenomenology had to develop from an “‘egological’ phenomenology” to a “sociological phenomenology”.5

在胡塞尔的晚期著作中，具身性、主体间性和时间性等主题被整合在一起思考。主体间性也具有历时性维度。最终，胡塞尔会思考主体的诞生于一个活生生的传统，才能产生构成性的意义。这不仅仅是因为我生活在一个充满了对他人的参照的世界，而其他人已经配备了意义，或者说，我通过一种传统的、流传下来的语言惯例来理解世界（和我自己）。世界对我而言的意义本身就在于，它起源于我之外，起源于历史的过去。正如胡塞尔在《危机》中所写，嵌入在“历史发展的单一流动”中——在诞生与……的生成性联结中。死亡——如同它的时间形式一样，不可分割地属于“我” 。6

In Husserl’s last writings, the topics of embodiment, intersubjectivity, and temporality are brought and thought together. There is also a diachronic dimension to intersubjectivity. Ultimately, Husserl would consider the subject’s birth into a living tradition to have constitutive implications. It is not merely the case that I live in a world which is permeated by references to others, and which others have already furnished with meaning, or that I understand the world (and myself) through a traditional, handed-down, linguistic conventionality. The very meaning that the world has for me is such that it has its origin outside of me, in a historical past. As Husserl writes in Crisis, being embedded in “the unitary flow of a historical development” – in a generative nexus of birth and death – belongs as indissolubly to the I as does its temporal form.6

事实上，胡塞尔最终将诸如体现等主题纳入其中，胡塞尔在先验分析中强调了历史性、主体间性，这也是梅洛-庞蒂在《知觉现象学》序言中写道“胡塞尔的先验不是康德的”的原因之一。7

The fact that Husserl eventually came to include topics such as embodiment, historicity, and intersubjectivity in his transcendental analysis is one of the reasons why Merleau-Ponty in the preface to Phenomenology of Perception could write: “Husserl’s transcendental is not Kant’s”.7

胡塞尔关于自我、他人和世界，从很早以前就被海德格尔和梅洛-庞蒂所探讨。他们同样坚持认为，自我、世界和他人是一体的；它们相互阐释，只有在相互联系中才能被理解。在早期的一次演讲中，海德格尔描述了生活世界是三个领域的相互渗透：周围世界、与世界和自我世界，8并认为作为世界体验者，此在始终是与他人共在（Mitsein）。正如他在1927年后期的讲座中所言：

Husserl’s late ideas regarding the intertwinement between self, others, and world is, from early on, also pursued by Heidegger and Merleau-Ponty, who likewise insist that self, world, and others belong together; that they reciprocally illuminate one another and can only be understood in their interconnection. In an early lecture, Heidegger describes the lifeworld as an interpenetration of the three domains: surrounding world, with-world, and self-world,8 and argues that Dasein as world-experiencing is always already being-with (Mitsein) others. As he would put it in later lectures from 1927:

此在起初并不只是栖居于事物之中，以至于后来偶尔在这些事物之中发现具有自身类型的存在者；相反，作为专注于自身的存在者，此在具有同等的独创性，既与他者共存，又与世界内部的存在者共存。9

dasein is just as little at first merely a dwelling among things so as then occasionally to discover among these things beings with its own kind of being; instead, as the being which is occupied with itself, the dasein is with equal originality being-with others and being-among intraworldly beings.9

至于梅洛-庞蒂，他认为主体性本质上是面向并开放于其非所是之物，正是在这种开放性中，主体性向自身展现自身。因此，现象学反思所揭示的并非自我封闭的心灵，并非纯粹的内在自我临在，而是一种面向他者的开放，一种外化运动和永恒的自我超越。正是通过临在于世界，我们才得以临在于自身；正是通过被赋予于自身，我们才能够意识到世界。10因此，梅洛-庞蒂坚持认为，现象学描述并非揭示那些不可接近且自足，揭示了主体间生活与世界之间的连续性。主体对自身、对世界、对他者都存在，并非无视其肉体性和历史性，而恰恰是通过其肉体性和历史性而存在。11正如梅洛-庞蒂所充分认识到的，这种关于自我、他者和世界交织的观念，影响着对先验哲学：

As for Merleau-Ponty, he argues that subjectivity is essentially oriented and open toward that which it is not, and that it is in this openness that it reveals itself to itself. What is disclosed by a phenomenological reflection is, consequently, not a self-enclosed mind, a pure interior self-presence, but an openness toward otherness, a movement of exteriorisation and perpetual self-transcendence. It is by being present to the world that we are present to ourselves, and it is by being given to ourselves that we can be conscious of the world.10 Merleau-Ponty consequently insists that a phenomenological description, rather than disclosing subjectivities that are inaccessible and self-sufficient, reveals continuities between intersubjective life and the world. The subject is present to itself, to the world, and to others, not in spite of, but precisely by way of its corporeality and historicity.11 As Merleau-Ponty fully realises, such a conception of the intertwinement of self, others, and world affects the very conception of transcendental philosophy:

先验与经验的界限如何能使人变得模糊不清？因为除了他人之外，其他人也看到了我——我所有的事实性——被重新整合到主观性中，或者至少被设定为其定义中不可或缺的元素。因此，先验性下降到历史。或者我们可以这样说，历史不再是两个或多个绝对自主的主体之间的外在关系，而是具有内在性，是其定义本身的内在方面。他们不再仅仅根据与个体自身的关系而认识自己是主体，也根据彼此之间的关系而认识自己是主体。12

[H]ow can the borders of the transcendental and the empirical help becoming indistinct? For along with the other person, all the other person sees of me – all my facticity – is reintegrated into subjectivity, or at least posited as an indispensable element of its definition. thus the transcendental descends into history. or as we might put it, the historical is no longer an external relation between two or more absolutely autonomous subjects but has an interior and is an inherent aspect of their very definition. they no longer know themselves to be subjects simply in relation to their individual selves, but in relation to one another as well.12

梅洛-庞蒂和海德格尔的现象学著作与胡塞尔的著作有何不同？理解这种差异的一种方式是，他们认为两者都在探寻胡塞尔的既有思想，但方式比胡塞尔本人更为激进。

How does the phenomenological work of Merleau-Ponty and Heidegger diverge from that of Husserl? One way to conceive of the divergence is by seeing both as pursuing ideas already found in Husserl in a more radical manner than Husserl himself.

梅洛-庞蒂比胡塞尔更重视具身性和事实性（即我们存在的偶然情境性）的作用，并更进一步尝试重新思考先验与经验、心灵与世界之间的传统划分。梅洛-庞蒂比胡塞尔更关注当代心理学和神经病学的讨论，这种兴趣也在他的著作中留下了印记。梅洛-庞蒂的首部重要著作《行为结构》（1942）广泛地探讨了经验科学，并在其最后一页呼吁重新定义先验哲学。13 梅洛-庞蒂并没有让我们在科学解释和现象学反思之间做出选择，而是要求我们尊重意识与自然之间的鲜活关系，并探寻一个超越两者的维度。客观主义和主观主义。这种方法在《知觉现象学》（1945）中得到了进一步的探讨，例如，梅洛-庞蒂在其中讨论了脑损伤患者约翰·施耐德 (Johann Schneider) 的神经学家库尔特·戈德斯坦 (Kurt Goldstein) 和神经心理学家阿德马尔·盖尔布 (Adhémar Gelb)。

Merleau-Ponty attributes more significance to the role of embodiment and facticity, i.e., the contingent situatedness of our existence, than Husserl, and also goes further in his attempt to rethink the traditional divide between the transcendental and the empirical and between mind and world. Merleau-Ponty was far more concerned with discussions in contemporary psychology and neurology than Husserl had been, and this interest also left its mark on his writings. Merleau-Ponty’s first major work, The Structure of Behavior (1942), engages extensively with empirical science and on its final page Merleau-Ponty calls for a redefinition of transcendental philosophy.13 Rather than making us choose between a scientific explanation and a phenomenological reflection, Merleau-Ponty asks us to respect the living relation between consciousness and nature and to search for a dimension that is beyond both objectivism and subjectivism. This approach is further pursued in Phenomenology of Perception (1945), where Merleau-Ponty, for instance, discusses studies by the neurologist Kurt Goldstein and the neuropsychologist Adhémar Gelb of the brain-damaged patient Johann Schneider.

海德格尔比胡塞尔更细心地阅读哲学史，也比胡塞尔更深刻地强调了我们当前思维在多大程度上受到传统的影响。对海德格尔而言，现象学的一项重要任务是揭示和解构几个世纪以来默默地框定和限制着哲学思维的一些形而上学概念。在海德格尔自身的现象学分析过程中，他开始质疑传统上对“海德格尔认为，胡塞尔的局限性之一在于他过于关注逻辑和认识论问题，从而运用了过于狭隘的存在和给予性概念。根据海德格尔的说法，胡塞尔的研究并非以事物本身为指导，而是被传统的，或者更确切地说，笛卡尔式的预设和决定所引导。通过优先考虑主动的自我，并将给予性简化为对象-给予性，胡塞尔不仅未能揭示意向性主体性所特有的独特存在模式，也未能充分探讨关于给予性本身的可能性条件这一真正先验的问题。14 在《存在与时间》之后的著作中，海德格尔自身对这些问题的思考使他开始质疑自己先前对此在。然而在《存在与时间》中，他仍然主张，一个根本的本体论必须根植于人类的生存，我们必须通过考察此在对存在的理解来探讨本体论问题。海德格尔随后认为，此在自身的理解源于一种更根本的澄明（Lichtung），这种澄明属于存在本身。正如海德格尔在1946年《论“人道主义”》一书中所写：

Heidegger is a more attentive reader of the history of philosophy than Husserl and is also, to a larger extent than Husserl, highlighting the extent to which our current thinking is influenced by the tradition. For Heidegger, one important task of phenomenology is to disclose and deconstruct some of the metaphysical conceptions that for centuries have tacitly framed and constrained philosophical thinking. In the course of his own phenomenological analysis, Heidegger came to question the traditional privileging of the theoretical attitude, of object-givenness, and of temporal presence. He argues that one of Husserl’s limitations was that he remained too focused on logical and epistemological issues and thereby operated with too narrow a concept of being and givenness. Rather than letting his investigation be guided by the things themselves, Husserl was, according to Heidegger, instead led by traditional, or to be more specific, by Cartesian presuppositions and decisions. By privileging the active ego, and by reducing givenness to object-given-ness, Husserl not only failed to disclose the unique mode of being peculiar to intentional subjectivity, he also failed to engage adequately with the truly transcendental question concerning the condition of possibility for givenness as such.14 In works succeeding Being and Time, Heidegger’s own wrestling with these issues led him to question his own prior privileging of Dasein. Whereas in Being and Time, he still argued that a fundamental ontology must be rooted in human existence and that we have to approach the ontological questions via an investigation of Dasein’s understanding of being, Heidegger subsequently came to hold the view that Dasein’s own understanding is enabled by a more fundamental clearing (Lichtung) that belongs to being itself. As Heidegger writes in Letter on “Humanism” from 1946:

人并非存在之主，而是存在的牧者。人并未因这种“缺失”而失去什么，反而有所收获，因为他们获得了存在的真理。他们获得了牧者本质的贫乏，而牧者的尊严在于被存在本身召唤去守护存在的真理。15

The human being is not the lord of beings. the human being is the shepherd of being. Human beings lose nothing in this “less”; rather, they gain in that they attain the truth of being. They gain the essential poverty of the shepherd, Whose dignity consists in being called by being itself into the preservation of being’s truth.15

到目前为止，我主要将现象学的发展描述为焦点的扩展。然而，人们也可以用一种略有不同的、更垂直的方式来描述这种发展。

So far, I have primarily been characterising the development of phenomenology as an expansion of focus. One might, however, also describe the development in a somewhat different, more vertical, manner.

不可见现象学

PHENOMENOLOGY OF THE INVISIBLE

人们习惯于区分表面现象学和深度现象学。前者则直接关注特定类型的对象与特定意向性行为之间的关联，也可以以更激进的方式进行。有时，胡塞尔谈到，如果要揭示和揭示主体的意向性活动如何建立在主观性的地下或深度维度中发生的各种被动性过程之上并受其制约，就需要进行精心的挖掘。16胡塞尔非常清楚，对这一被动且匿名运作的维度的任何描述都充满困难，主要是因为我们所掌握的概念主要源于我们与世俗对象的互动。因此，一个挑战是避免在我们对体验生活的描述中引入过于清晰的区别和过度客观化的结构和类别。意识到这些困难，胡塞尔曾强调，主体性的最基本维度“几乎处于可能描述的极限” 。17

It has become customary to distinguish surface phenomenology from depth phenomenology. Whereas the former focuses squarely on the correlation between specific types of objects and specific intentional acts, it is also possible to proceed in a more radical manner. Sometimes, Husserl speaks of the need for an elaborate mining effort if one is to uncover and disclose how the intentional activity of the subject is founded upon and conditioned by various processes of passivity taking place in the underground or depth-dimension of subjectiv-ity.16 Husserl was well aware of the fact that any description of this passive and anonymously functioning dimension is beset with difficulties, mainly because the concepts we have at our disposal primarily originate from our interaction with worldly objects. One challenge is, consequently, to avoid importing too clear distinctions and overly objectifying structures and categories into our description of experiential life. Realising these difficulties, Husserl at one point emphasised that the most fundamental dimension of subjectivity “lies almost at the limit of possible description”.17

更广泛地说，胡塞尔充分认识到，对象意向性，即我们对对象的意识和关注，并不会耗尽心灵的生命，事实上，它本身就具有各种先决条件。胡塞尔对结构的研究时间意识常被视为胡塞尔在刻画和分析最根本的现象学维度方面最激进的尝试。胡塞尔对时间意识的广泛探讨中，一个值得关注的特点恰恰在于，他最终意识到，除了对象显现之外，还存在其他显现形式（由此也质疑了海德格尔批判的准确性），并且意识的时间自我显现遵循着与桌椅显现截然不同的原则和结构。

More generally speaking, Husserl fully recognised that object-intentionality, our consciousness of and preoccupation with objects, doesn’t exhaust the life of the mind and, indeed, has various preconditions of its own. Husserl’s investigation into the structures of time-consciousness is often viewed as his most radical attempt at characterising and analysing the most fundamental phenomenological dimension. One noteworthy feature of Husserl’s extensive engagement with time-consciousness is precisely that he eventually came to realise that there are other forms of manifestation than object-manifestation (thereby also questioning the accuracy of Heidegger’s criticism), and that the temporal self-manifestation of consciousness is subjected to very different principles and structures than the manifestation of chairs and tables.

海德格尔在《存在与时间》中的一句名言中指出，现象学的具体任务是揭示那些首先隐藏在视线之外的东西。事实上，正是因为有些现象不会立即显现出来，我们才需要现象学。18很久以后，在 1973 年的一次会议上，海德格尔明确谈到了对“不明显现象学”的需要。19在这个方向上拓展现象学界限的最持久的尝试或许可以在米歇尔·亨利的著作中找到，他试图发展所谓的不可见现象学。简而言之，亨利的想法是，主观性不会在世界的光芒下、在世俗外在性的可见性中显现出来。纯粹的主观性不会将自己表现为世俗对象，也不能通过属于世俗外表的范畴来捕捉。相反，正如亨利写道：

In a famous remark in Being and Time, Heidegger observes that the specific task of phenomenology is to disclose that which first and foremost remains hidden from view. Indeed, it is exactly because there are phenomena that do not reveal themselves immediately that we are in need of a phenomenology.18 Much later, in a conference from 1973, Heidegger explicitly spoke of the need for a “phenomenology of the inapparent”.19 The perhaps most sustained attempt to push the boundaries of phenomenology in this direction can be found in the work of Michel Henry who sought to develop what has been called a phenomenology of the invisible. Briefly put, Henry’s idea was that subjectivity does not reveal itself in the light of the world, in the visibility of worldly exteriority. Pure subjectivity does not reveal itself as a worldly object and cannot be captured through categories pertaining to worldly appearance. Rather, as Henry writes:

基础并不是某种模糊的东西，也不是只有当它照耀在沐浴着它的光的事物上时才变得可感知的光，也不是作为“超越现象”的事物本身，而是一种内在的启示，它对自身而言是一种在场，尽管这种在场仍然是“不可见的” 。20

The foundation is not something obscure, neither is it light which becomes perceivable only when it shines upon the thing which bathes in its light, nor is it the thing itself as a “transcendent phenomenon”, but it is an immanent revelation which is a presence to itself, even though such a presence remains “invisible”.20

亨利的建议并非是现象学应该放弃对显化的兴趣，转而进行不受约束的思辨。对他而言，谈论不可见之物，并非谈论永远隐藏的事物，并非谈论永远不会显化自身之物，而只是谈论一种以与可见之物截然不同的方式显化自身之物。

Henry’s suggestion is not that phenomenology should abandon its interest in manifestation and instead engage in unconstrained speculations. To speak of the invisible is, for him, not to speak of something that forever remains hidden, it is not to speak of something that never manifests itself, but simply to speak of something that manifests itself in a radically different manner than the visible.

大多数现象学家都认同现象学必须超越对客体意向性和客体显现的执着和固着。这不仅是因为我们最根本的自我认知并非以客体关系的形式呈现，我们与世界最根本的关系并非与某个客体或客体复合体的关系，更因为我们与另一个主体的本真关系恰恰是与超越我们客体化理解的某个人的关系。

The idea that phenomenology has to move beyond an occupation and fixation with object-intentionality and object-manifestation is shared by most phenomenologists. This is so, not only because our most fundamental self-acquaintance does not take the form of an object-relation, and because our most fundamental relation to the world is not a relation to an object or complex of objects, but also because our authentic relationship to another subject is precisely a relation to someone that transcends our objectifying grasp.

虽然这些思想在胡塞尔的著作中已经以初步形式出现，但毫无疑问，像伊曼纽尔这样的后期思想家列维纳斯、米歇尔·亨利和雅克·德里达通过批判性地研究意向性、时间意识、主体间性、语言等古典现象学研究，彻底改变了人们揭示新表现类型的努力，从而也为现象学的发展做出了重要贡献。

Although these ideas can already be found in rudimentary form in Husserl, there is no question that later thinkers like Emmanuel Levinas, Michel Henry, and Jacques Derrida, through their critical engagement with the classical phenomenological investigations of intentionality, time-consciousness, intersubjectivity, language, etc., radicalised the effort to disclose new types of manifestation, and thereby also made important contributions to the development of phenomenology.

笔记

进一步阅读的建议

SUGGESTIONS FOR FURTHER READING

  • 弗朗索瓦丝·达斯图尔，《1961年以后的法国现象学》。载M. Sinclair和D. Whistler编，《牛津现代法国哲学手册》（第319-333页）。牛津：牛津大学出版社，2024年。

  • 雅克·德里达，《暴力与形而上学：论埃马纽埃尔·列维纳斯思想》。载J.德里达著《写作与差异》，艾伦·巴斯译（第79-153页）。伦敦：劳特利奇出版社，1995年。

  • Martin C. Dillon, “Merleau-Ponty and the reversibility thesis.” Man and World 16(4), 1983, 365–388.
  • 丹·扎哈维，《米歇尔·亨利与无形现象学》。《大陆哲学评论》 32(3)，1999，223–240。
  • Dan Zahavi, “Michel Henry and the phenomenology of the invisible.” Continental Philosophy Review 32(3), 1999, 223–240.

6梅洛-庞蒂《知觉现象学》序言

6 MERLEAU-PONTY'S PREFACE TO PHENOMENOLOGY OF PERCEPTION

DOI：10.4324/9781003350682-8

DOI: 10.4324/9781003350682-8

让我以梅洛-庞蒂为其最著名的著作《知觉现象学》所写的著名序言作为第一部分的结束。这篇序言试图对“什么是现象学？”这个问题给出一个简短的回答。由于梅洛-庞蒂在他的讨论中借鉴了胡塞尔和海德格尔的洞见，这篇序言很适合用来做出细致入微的回应。

Let me conclude Part I by looking at the famous preface that MerleauPonty wrote to his most well-known work, Phenomenology of Perception. The preface seeks to give a short answer to the question “What is phenomenology?” Since Merleau-Ponty, in his discussion, draws on insights from both Husserl and Heidegger, the preface is a suitable candidate for a nuanced reply.

正如梅洛-庞蒂开篇所言，即使在胡塞尔的首部著作问世半个世纪之后，现象学仍然缺乏一个明确的定义。事实上，许多提出的建议似乎指向不同的方向：

As Merleau-Ponty starts out by observing, even half a century after Husserl’s first writings a univocal definition of phenomenology is still missing. In fact, many of the proposals given seem to point in different directions:

  1. 一方面，现象学的特点是本质主义。它并不关注对不同现象的纯粹经验性或事实性的描述，相反，它寻求揭示例如意识流、具身性、知觉等的不变结构。然而，另一方面，它研究世界和人类存在的出发点仍然是事实性的存在。现象学不仅仅是本质主义的一种形式，它也是一门关于實際性。
  2. On the one hand, phenomenology is characterised by a form of essentialism. It is not interested in a merely empirical or factual account of different phenomena, but seeks, on the contrary, to disclose the invariant structures of, for example, the stream of consciousness, embodiment, perception, etc. On the other hand, however, the point of departure for its investigation of the world and human existence remains factual existence. Phenomenology is not simply a form of essentialism, it is also a philosophy of facticity.
  3. 现象学是一种先验哲学。它试图揭示意向经验的可能性条件它超越了我们自然的、日常的形而上学假设（特别是关于存在一个独立于心灵的世界的假设），以便对其进行批判性探究。然而，与此同时，它承认反思必须从与世界既存的关系出发，而哲学的核心任务之一就是理解这种与世界的直接联系。
  4. Phenomenology is a form of transcendental philosophy. It seeks to disclose the conditions of possibility of intentional experience and worldly objectivity, and it suspends our natural and everyday metaphysical assumptions (in particular, our assumption about the existence of a mind-independent world) in order to investigate them critically. At the same time, however, it concedes that reflection must start from an already existing relation to the world, and that a central task of philosophy is to comprehend this immediate and direct contact with the world.
  5. 现象学致力于建立一种严格的科学哲学，但它也肩负着解释我们的生活世界和公正对待我们在科学之前对空间、时间和世界的经验的任务。
  6. Phenomenology seeks to establish a strictly scientific philosophy, but it also has the task of accounting for our lifeworld and of doing justice to our pre-scientific experience of space, time, and world.
  7. 现象学经常被描述为一门纯粹的描述性学科。它描述我们经验的本来面目。它既不关注经验的神经生理学或生物学起源，也不寻求提供因果解释。但与此同时，胡塞尔本人也强调了发展发生现象学的重要性，即分析起源、发展和……的现象学。有意结构的历史性。
  8. Phenomenology is frequently described as a purely descriptive discipline. It describes our experiences just as they are given. It is interested neither in the neurophysiological nor the biological origins of the experiences, nor does it seek to provide a causal account. But at the same time, Husserl himself had emphasised the importance of developing a genetic phenomenology, i.e., a phenomenology that analyses the origin, development, and historicity of the intentional structures.

正如梅洛-庞蒂所言，人们或许倾向于简单地区分胡塞尔的（先验的）现象学和海德格尔的（解释学和存在主义的）现象学，试图克服这些表面上的差异。胡塞尔的现象学常被视为试图将纯粹不变的认知条件主题化，而海德格尔的现象学常被解读为试图揭示我们存在于世的历史和实践语境。但梅洛-庞蒂很快驳斥了这种想法，认为它过于天真。他指出，所有提到的对比都可以在胡塞尔的思想中找到内在的体现。此外，更重要的是，我们讨论的并非真正的对比或替代，而是现象学（如果理解得当）必然包含和融入的互补方面。1

As Merleau-Ponty remarks, it might be tempting to seek to overcome these apparent discrepancies by simply differentiating between Husserl’s (transcendental) phenomenology, which has often been seen as an attempt to thematise the pure and invariant conditions of cognition, and Heidegger’s (hermeneutical and existential) phenomenology, which has frequently been interpreted as an attempt to disclose the historical and practical contextuality of our being-in-the-world. But Merleau-Ponty quickly rejects this suggestion as being too naive. As he points out, all the contrasts mentioned can be found internally in Husserl’s thinking. Moreover, and more importantly, we are not dealing with true contrasts or alternatives, but rather with complementary aspects that phenomenology (if properly understood) necessarily includes and incorporates.1

胡塞尔的名言“梅洛-庞蒂将“对事物本身”的批判解读为科学主义，并试图揭示一种比科学理性所体现的更原始的世界关系。它呼吁回归感知经验的世界，这种世界先于世界，也比世界更为根本。科学概念化和表述的复杂性。科学主义试图将我们还原为世界中的客体，这些客体可以通过客观化的理论（例如物理学、生物学或心理学）得到详尽的解释。它认为自然科学的方法提供了认识论视角理解世界的唯一途径，而那些无法用自然科学所接受的术语来捕捉的实体是不存在的。然而，正如梅洛-庞蒂所坚持的那样，我们永远不应忘记，我们对世界的认知，包括我们的科学知识，都源于一种基于身体的第一人称视角，如果没有这种体验维度，科学就毫无意义。科学话语根植于经验世界，根植于经验世界。如果我们想要理解科学的运作和局限性，就应该探究世界的原始经验，而科学正是这种经验的高阶表达。科学片面地关注从经验中可以获得什么，因此，在梅洛-庞蒂看来，第三人称视角既幼稚又不诚实，因为科学实践始终预设着科学家对世界的第一人称和前科学经验。2

Husserl’s dictum “to the things themselves” is interpreted by Merleau-Ponty as a criticism of scientism, and as an attempt to disclose a more original relation to the world than the one manifested in scientific rationality. It is a call for a return to the world of perceptual experience that is prior to and more fundamental than the world of scientific conceptualisation and articulation. Scientism seeks to reduce us to objects in the world, objects that can be exhaustively explained by objectifying theories like those of physics, biology, or psychology. It argues that the methods of natural science provide the sole means of epistemic access to the world, and that entities that cannot be captured in terms accepted by natural science are nonexistent. As Merleau-Ponty insists, however, we should never forget that our knowledge of the world, including our scientific knowledge, arises from a bodily anchored first-person perspective, and that science would be meaningless without this experiential dimension. The scientific discourse is rooted in the world of experience, in the experiential world, and if we wish to comprehend the performance and limits of science, we should investigate the original experience of the world of which science is a higher-order articulation. The one-sided focus of science on what is available from a third-person perspective is, for Merleau-Ponty, consequently both naive and dishonest, since the scientific practice constantly presupposes the scientist’s first-personal and pre-scientific experience of the world.2

现象学强调第一人称视角的重要性，不应与古典（先验）唯心主义试图将心灵与世界分离，以便让纯粹的、无世界的主体构成世界的丰富性和具体性混为一谈。这种尝试同样幼稚。主体并不优先于世界，真理也不存在于人的内在性中。内在性并不存在，因为人存在于世界中，只有通过栖居于世界中才能认识自己。换句话说，现象学反思所揭示的主体性并非一种隐蔽的内在性，而是一种开放的世界关系。3 用海德格尔的话来说，我们处理的正是在世界中的存在，这个世界不应被理解为客体的单纯总体，或因果关系的总和，而应被理解为意思是我们始终处于其中。

Phenomenology’s highlighting of the importance of the first-person perspective should not be conflated with the classical (transcendental) idealistic attempt to detach the mind from the world in order to let a pure and worldless subject constitute the richness and concreteness of the world. This attempt was also naive. The subject has no priority over the world, and truth is not to be found in the interiority of man. There is no interiority, since man is in the world, and only knows him- or herself by means of inhabiting the world. To put it differently, the subjectivity disclosed by the phenomenological reflection is not a concealed interiority, but an open worldrelation.3 To use Heidegger’s phrase, we are precisely dealing with a being-in-the-world, a world that moreover should not be understood as the mere totality of objects, or as the sum total of causal relations, but rather as the context of meaning that we are constantly situated within.

有如果理想主义是真的，世界只是我们构成和建构，世界将会呈现出完全透明的状态。它只拥有我们赋予它的意义，因此不包含任何隐藏的方面，也不包含任何神秘感。唯心主义和建构主义剥夺了世界它的超越。对于这样的立场，知识自我、世界、他人不再是问题。但事情变得更加复杂。

Had idealism been true, had the world been a mere product of our constitution and construction, the world would have appeared in full transparency. It would only possess the meaning that we ascribed to it and would consequently contain no hidden aspects, no sense of mystery. Idealism and constructivism deprive the world of its transcendence. For such positions, knowledge of self, world, and other are no longer a problem. But things are more complicated.

仔细的现象学分析将会揭示，我并非仅仅为自己而存在，也为他人而存在，正如他人并非仅仅为自己而存在，也为我而存在。主体并非垄断了其对自我的理解，也并非垄断了其对世界的理解。相反，自我的某些方面和世界的某些方面，只有通过他者才能获得和触及。简而言之，我的存在不仅仅是我如何理解自己的问题，也是他人如何理解我的问题。主体性必然植根于并体现在社会、历史和自然的语境中。世界与主体性密不可分，并且主体间性，而现象学的任务就是思考世界、主体性和主体间性之间的恰当联系。4

As a careful phenomenological analysis will reveal, I do not simply exist for myself, but also for others, just as others do not simply exist for themselves, but also for me. The subject does not have a monopoly, either on its self-understanding or on its understanding of the world. On the contrary, there are aspects of myself and aspects of the world that only become available and accessible through the other. In short, my existence is not simply a question of how I apprehend myself, it is also a question of how others apprehend me. Subjectivity is necessarily embedded and embodied in a social, historical, and natural context. The world is inseparable from subjectivity and intersubjectivity, and the task of phenomenology is to think world, subjectivity, and intersubjectivity in their proper connection.4

我们与世界的关系如此根本、如此显而易见且自然，以至于我们通常不会去反思它。现象学试图探究的正是这个被忽视的显而易见的领域。现象学的任务并非获取关于世界不同领域的新经验知识，而是理解任何此类经验研究所预设的与世界的基本关系。当现象学强调一种反思性克制（胡塞尔称之为“回溯”（epoché）和还原）的方法论必要性时，这并非因为现象学有意抛弃世界而转向纯粹意识，而是因为我们只有通过稍微放松那些将我们与世界联系在一起的意向性线索，才能使它们变得可见。正如梅洛-庞蒂所言，世界是奇妙的。它是一份礼物，也是一个谜。但为了认识到这一点，我们必须暂停我们通常盲目且轻率地将世界视为理所当然的做法。通常情况下，我生活在一种自然而投入的世界关系中。但作为一名哲学家，我无法接受这种天真的世界沉浸。为了能够解释它，我必须与之保持距离，哪怕只是一点点。这就是为什么梅洛-庞蒂认为，对我们在世存在的分析，预设了现象学还原。5

Our relation to the world is so fundamental, so obvious and natural, that we normally do not reflect upon it. It is this domain of ignored obviousness that phenomenology seeks to investigate. The task of phenomenology is not to obtain new empirical knowledge about different areas in the world, but rather to comprehend the basic relation to the world that is presupposed by any such empirical investigation. When phenomenology emphasises the methodological necessity of a type of reflective restraint – what Husserl has called the epoché and reduction – this is not because phenomenology intends to desert the world in favour of pure consciousness, but because we can only make those intentional threads that attach us to the world visible by slacking them slightly. The world is, as Merleau-Ponty writes, wonderful. It is a gift and a riddle. But in order to realise this, it is necessary to suspend our ordinary blind and thoughtless taking of the world for granted. Normally, I live in a natural and engaged world-relation. But as a philosopher, I cannot make do with such a naive world-immersion. I must distance myself from it, if ever so slightly, in order to be able to account for it. This is why Merleau-Ponty argues that an analysis of our being-in-the-world presupposes the phenomenological reduction.5

现象学研究从事实出发，直达本质，但分析并非止于此。关注本质并非目标，而是一种理解、概念化和表达我们现实存在深度的手段。关注关注本质结构是出于捕捉事实丰富性的愿望，而不是出于抽象和忽略的愿望。真实性。6

The phenomenological investigation proceeds from the factual to the essential, but that is not where the analysis ends. The focus on the essential is not the goal, but a means to understand, conceptualise, and articulate the depth of our factual existence. The focus on essential structures is due to a wish to capture the richness of the factual, and not because of a desire to abstract from and ignore facticity.6

分析意向性，即对意识的指向性或围绕性的分析，常被视为现象学的核心成就之一。人们不仅仅是爱、恐惧、观察或评判，他们还会爱所爱之人，恐惧可怕的事物，观察客体，并评判事态。无论我们谈论的是感知、思考、判断、幻想、怀疑、期待还是回忆，所有这些不同的意识形式都以意向性客体为特征，如果不考察它们的客观对应物（例如，被感知、怀疑或期待的客体），就无法对其进行正确的分析。因此，主体触及客体并非难事，因为客体的存在是意向性的。也就是说，主体本身就是自我超越的，本身指向不同于自身的东西。但除了详细分析了我们理论中的客体指向性之外，现象学还明确指出，世界是先于任何分析、认同和客观化而存在的。简而言之，也存在着一种与世界前理论和非理论的关系。正如梅洛-庞蒂所指出的，这就是胡塞尔区分两种意向性的原因。一种是胡塞尔在《逻辑研究》中所说的行为意向性，它是意向性的一种客观化形式。但也存在一种更根本的被动或操作形式的非客观化意向性，胡塞尔在其后期的一些著作中对此进行了详细的分析。根据梅洛-庞蒂的说法，这种原始的、基本的世界关系无法进一步解释或分析。现象学所能做的就是引起人们对它的关注，并让我们尊重它的不可还原性。7

The analysis of intentionality, the analysis of the directedness or aboutness of consciousness, is often presented as one of the central accomplishments of phenomenology. One does not merely love, fear, see, or judge, one loves a beloved, fears something fearful, sees an object, and judges a state of affairs. Regardless of whether we are talking about a perception, thought, judgment, fantasy, doubt, expectation, or recollection, all of these diverse forms of consciousness are characterised by intending objects and cannot be analysed properly without a look at their objective correlate, e.g., the perceived, doubted, or expected object. It is, consequently, not a problem for the subject to reach the object, since its being is intentional. That is, the subject is per se self-transcending, per se directed towards something different from itself. But apart from having analysed our theoretical object-directedness in great detail, phenomenology has also made it clear that the world is given prior to any analysis, identification, and objectification. There is, in short, also a pre- and a-theoretical relation to the world. As Merleau-Ponty points out, this is why Husserl distinguished two types of intentionality. There is what Husserl in Logical Investigations called act-intentionality, which is an objectifying form of intentionality. But there is also a more fundamental passive or operative form of non-objectifying intentionality, which Husserl analysed in detail in some of his later works. According to Merleau-Ponty, this original and basic world-relation cannot be explained or analysed further. All phenomenology can do is to call attention to it and make us respect its irreducibility.7

梅洛-庞蒂将现象学描述为一种永恒的批判性（自我）反思。它不应将任何事物视为理所当然，尤其是它自身。换句话说，它是一种持续的冥想。8梅洛-庞蒂在此的观点是，现象学始终在路上。这一点在梅洛-庞蒂的著名论断“还原的最重要的教训是不可能完全还原”中得到了体现。9还原必须被视为一种特殊的反思性举动，梅洛-庞蒂的观点是，作为有限的生物，我们无法实现一种绝对的反思，这种反思一劳永逸地让我们切断与沉浸于世界的生活的联系，以便从虚无缥缈的视角。即使是最彻底的反思也依赖于并关联于一种未经反思的生活，正如梅洛-庞蒂所说，这种生活依然是其初始、恒定和最终的处境。10说还原无法完成，并非说它无法进行。但这个过程必须反复进行，而不是一劳永逸地完成。就此而言，梅洛-庞蒂关于现象学未完成性以及关于还原不完全性的评论，是阐述同一观点的两种方式。然而，正如梅洛-庞蒂最后指出的那样，现象学尚未完成，它始终在进行中，这并非需要修补的缺陷或瑕疵，而是其本质特征之一。作为世界奇迹，现象学并非一个坚实僵化的体系，而是处于不断的运动之中。11

Merleau-Ponty characterises phenomenology as a perpetual critical (self-)reflection. It should not take anything for granted, least of all itself. It is, to put it differently, a constant meditation.8 Merleau-Ponty’s point here is that phenomenology is always en route. This also comes to the fore in Merleau-Ponty’s famous assertion that “the most important lesson of the reduction is the impossibility of a complete reduction”.9 The reduction must be seen as a particular reflective move, and Merleau-Ponty’s point is that we as finite creatures are incapable of effectuating an absolute reflection that once and for all would allow us to cut our ties to our world-immersed life in order to survey it from a view from nowhere. Even the most radical reflection depends upon and is linked to an unreflected life that, as Merleau-Ponty puts it, remains its initial, constant, and final situation.10 To say that the reduction cannot be completed is not to say that it cannot be carried out. But this procedure is something that has to be performed repeatedly, rather than completed once and for all. To that extent, Merleau-Ponty’s remarks about the unfinished character of phenomenology and about the incomplete reduction are two ways of making the same point. As Merleau-Ponty points out in closing, however, the fact that phenomenology remains unfinished, the fact that it is always under way, is not a defect or flaw that should be mended, but rather one of its essential features. As a wonder over the world, phenomenology is not a solid and inflexible system, but rather in constant movement.11

笔记

SUGGESTIONS FOR FURTHER READING

  • Martin C. Dillon, Merleau-Ponty’s Ontology. 2nd edn. Evanston, IL: Northwestern University Press, 1997.
