  • Ted Toadvine, “Maurice Merleau-Ponty.” In E.N. Zalta and U. Nodelman (eds.), The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, 2023: https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/win2023/entries/merleau-ponty/.

第二部分 具体分析

PART II CONCRETE ANALYSIS

DOI：10.4324/9781003350682-9

DOI: 10.4324/9781003350682-9

在阐述了现象学哲学的本质，并讨论了一些基本的现象学概念和区别之后，现在是时候来探讨现象学的运作方式了。现象学以其细致的研究而闻名，下文我将通过一些具体的现象学分析来展现其丰富的内涵。首先，我将考察以下现象学探索：空间性和具体性，然后转向主体间性和社区，最后讨论所谓的批判现象学。

After having characterised the nature of phenomenological philosophy and discussed a number of fundamental phenomenological concepts and distinctions, it is now time to see phenomenology at work. Phenomenology is rightly renowned for its meticulous investigations, and in the following I will exemplify this richness by considering some concrete phenomenological analyses. I will first examine phenomenological explorations of spatiality and embodiment, then turn to analyses of intersubjectivity and community, and finally discuss what has become known as critical phenomenology.

7空间性与体现

7 SPATIALITY AND EMBODIMENT

DOI：10.4324/9781003350682-10

DOI: 10.4324/9781003350682-10

海德格尔在《存在与时间》中的一个重要观点是，哲学传统过于专注于一种特定的存在，即客体的存在。因此，它也倾向于将人类，即我们自身这样的存在，视为客体。乍一看，这似乎是一个奇怪的说法；毕竟，包括笛卡尔、洛克和休谟在内的早期现代哲学不是一直在强调主观性的重要性吗？然而，在海德格尔看来，普遍的倾向是将主观性视为一种自足的、无世界的实体，即一种非常特殊的孤立客体。然而，这种思路完全未能公正地对待我们自身独特的存在方式。我们首先是由我们与……的关系构成的存在。我们所居住的世界。

One of Heidegger’s influential claims in Being and Time is that the philosophical tradition has been too preoccupied and concerned with a specific kind of being, namely the being of objects. As a result, it has also tended to view human beings, i.e., the kind of beings that we ourselves are, as objects. This might at first seem like a strange claim; after all, has early modern philosophy including Descartes, Locke, and Hume not precisely been highlighting the importance of subjectivity? According to Heidegger, however, there has been a widespread tendency to conceive of subjectivity as a self-contained and worldless substance, i.e., as a very special kind of isolated object. Such an approach has, however, utterly failed to do justice to our own distinctive mode of being. We are first and foremost beings constituted by our relationship to the very world that we inhabit.

存在于世

BEING-IN-THE-WORLD

为了与传统观念决裂，海德格尔引入了“此在（Dasein）指的是我们自身是什么样的存在者， 《存在与时间》的大部分内容都致力于分析其基本特征，特别是其所谓的“在世存在”（In-der-Welt-sein）。正如海德格尔所指出的，我们需要明确区分此在的生存论“在中”和事物的范畴论“在中”。此在存在于世界中的方式不同于T恤衫存在于衣柜中——也就是说，它不是一个被包含在另一个扩展实体中的扩展实体。事实上，鉴于海德格尔将世界定义为“此在”所栖息的意义和重要性的语境，而非一个空的空间或所有对象的总和，因此，根据海德格尔的说法，只有此在才具有在世的特征，这也就不足为奇了。相比之下，其他类型的实体是“内在世界的”或“属于世界的”，但世界对它们来说并不“存在”，它们没有世界。1

To mark the rupture with traditional conceptions, Heidegger introduced the term Dasein to designate the kind of beings we ourselves are, and most of Being and Time is devoted to an analysis of its fundamental features, in particular its so-called being-in-the-world (In-der-Welt-sein). As Heidegger points out, we need to distinguish sharply between the existential “Being-in” of Dasein and the categorial “being in” of things. Dasein is not in the world in the same way as a t-shirt is in a closet – that is to say, as one extended entity being contained within another extended entity. In fact, given that Heidegger defines the world, not as an empty space or as the sum total of all objects, but rather as the context of meaning and significance that Dasein inhabits, it is no wonder that only Dasein, according to Heidegger, is characterised by being-in-the-world. Other types of entities, by contrast, are “innerworldly” or “belong to the world”, but the world is not “there” for them, they have no world.1

对海德格尔而言，世俗介入是此在的构成要素，即此在不可缺少的本质特征。而且，这种介入并非主要采取一种超然的理论观察和对超然对象的沉思——海德格尔称之为现成的。相反，我们首先遇到的实体是即手可得的，即我们可以抓取、操纵和使用的实体。事实上，正是在实际使用中，通过处理、使用和照料事物，它们才展现出自身的本质。正如海德格尔所写：

For Heidegger, worldly engagement is a constitutive feature of Dasein, i.e., an essential feature that Dasein cannot lack. Moreover, this engagement does not primarily take the form of a detached theoretical observation and contemplation of detached objects, of what Heidegger terms the present-at-hand. Rather, the kind of entities we first and foremost encounter are entities that are ready-to-hand, entities that we can grab, manipulate, and use. Indeed, it is in practical use, it is by handling, using, and taking care of things, that they show themselves as what they are. As Heidegger writes:

我们越少只是盯着锤子这个东西，就越积极地使用它，我们与它的关系就越原始，我们就越能坦然地将它视为一个有用之物。敲击的动作本身就揭示了锤子特有的“便捷性” 。2

The less we just stare at the thing called hammer, the more actively we use it, the more original our relation to it becomes and the more undisguisedly it is encountered as what it is, as a useful thing. The act of hammering itself discovers the specific “handiness” of the hammer.2

更概括地说，并非认知（此处狭义地理解为对对象的理论审视）确立了此在与世界之间的关系。相反，在认知中，此在与一个已然显露的世界中的存在体建立了一种新的关系。认知是对我们原始的在世存在（being-in-the-world）的一种衍生性修正，它之所以可能，是因为我们已经存在于世。正是由于我们与现成之物（ready-to-hand）的实践接触，才使得对此类存在体进行理论探索之类的事情成为可能。正是因为我们使用了吸尘器，才有可能出现这种使用受到干扰的情况，例如，如果吸尘器清洁剂不再正常工作，正是在那时，我们不再专注于手头的工作，而是开始注意并审视器具本身，将其视为具有延展性、重量、颜色等的现成物体。3

More generally speaking, it is not cognition (here understood narrowly as a theoretical scrutiny of objects) that establishes the relation between Dasein and world. Rather, in cognition, Dasein established a new kind of relationship to entities in an already disclosed world. Cognition is a derived modification of our primary being-in-the-world and is only possible because we already are in the world. It is only because of our practical engagement with the ready-to-hand that something like a theoretical exploration of such entities becomes possible. It is only because we use the vacuum cleaner that circumstances can occur where that use is disturbed, say, if the vacuum cleaner ceases to work properly, and it is precisely then that, rather than being absorbed in the job at hand, we start to notice and scrutinise the utensil itself as a present-at-hand object that possesses extension, weight, colour, etc.3

在《存在与时间》第 22 节中，海德格尔提出了关于内在世界实体的空间性。毫不奇怪，他最初对上手之物的空间性感兴趣，因为他的出发点是我们首先遇到的实体类型。正如海德格尔所指出的，“首先”一词不仅具有时间含义，也具有空间含义。空间首先是上手之物的特征，而非一个可以随后用物体填充的空容器。只有当我们的实际操作受到干扰时，我们才会注意到纯粹的空间；只有当手电筒不在预期的位置时，我们才会注意到抽屉是一个空容器。

In section 22 of Being and Time, Heidegger raises the question regarding the spatiality of innerworldly entities. Not surprisingly, he is at first interested in the spatiality of the ready-to-hand, since his point of departure is the kind of entities that we first and foremost encounter. As Heidegger points out, the expression “first and foremost” does not merely have a temporal, but also a spatial connotation. Space is in the first instance a feature of the ready-to-hand, and not an empty container which can subsequently be filled with objects. It is only when our practical dealings are disturbed that we notice mere space; it is only when the flashlight is not where we expected to find it that we notice the drawer as an empty container.

我们首先遇到的是近在咫尺的事物。鉴于海德格尔拒绝接受“现成的”的首要性，近在咫尺不应以几何学的术语来解释。如果现成的物品触手可及且可用，那么它就是近在咫尺的。更具体地说，现成物品的空间性，即它的位置，在于它嵌入到特定的使用情境中，它所属于此并发挥其功能，而非它在三维空间中的位置。只有在这种实用的情境中，器具才具有意义、相关性和可用性。单个器具从不孤立存在，而是始终交织在指向其他器的网络中。邮票只有在包含信封或明信片的世界中才有意义；钢笔用于书写，指的是墨水和纸张；锤子只有在钉子和木板等其他器具的情境中才是锤子。当我们询问某物在哪里时，我们的问题关乎它在这种网络中的位置。空间维度——上方、下方、旁边等等——具有如此实际而具体的指向。距离无法用绝对的术语来定义，而是与环境、实际关切和兴趣相关。同样，最接近的事物不一定是距离自身身体“客观”距离最短的事物。相反，它是此在所关注的、能够伸手去拿、抓住或看见。将某物拉近，就是将其纳入到令人关切的交往和使用中。举几个具体的例子：

That which we first and foremost encounter is that which is nearby. Given Heidegger’s rejection of the primacy of the present-at-hand, nearness is not to be interpreted in geometrical terms. The ready-to-hand is nearby if it is accessible and usable. More specifically, the spatiality of the ready-to-hand, its place, is a matter of its embeddedness in a specific context of use, where it belongs and has its functionality, and not a matter of its location in three-dimensional space. It is only within such a pragmatic context that the utensil has significance, relevance, and usability. Single pieces of equipment never stand alone, but are always enmeshed in a network of references to other pieces of equipment. A stamp is only meaningful in a world that contains envelopes or postcards; a pen is for writing and refers to ink and paper; a hammer is a hammer only in the context of other equipment such as nails and boards. When we ask where something is, our question concerns its location within such a network. The spatial dimensions – above, beneath, next to, etc. – have such practical and concrete references. Distance cannot be defined in absolute terms, but is relative to context, practical concerns, and interests. Likewise, that which is closest by is not necessarily that which is at the shortest “objective” distance from one’s own body. Rather, it is that which Dasein is concerned with, can reach out for, catch hold of, or see. To bring something closer is to incorporate it in the context of concernful dealings and use. To give a few concrete examples:

  • 从几何学上讲，我离我所站立的地面或我所戴的眼镜比离我正在看的画作更近，而现象学的描述会声称我离画作更近，而不是离地面或我的眼镜更近。4
  • Whereas geometrically, I am closer to the ground on which I am standing, or the spectacles I am wearing, than to the painting I am looking at, a phenomenological description will claim that I am closer to the painting than to the ground or my spectacles.4
  • 从几何学角度来看，哥本哈根和新德里之间的距离与100年前几乎相同。然而，从实际情况来看，这段距离已经大幅缩短——至少对于我们这些负担得起机票的人来说是如此。
  • Geometrically, the distance between Copenhagen and New Delhi is pretty much the same as it was 100 years ago. Pragmatically, however, the distance has been reduced dramatically – at least for those of us who can afford the flight.
  • 在两条路径中选择一条来实现某个目标时，几何上最短的路径并不总是实用上最接近目标的。如果你忘了带钥匙，正站在锁着的前门外，门厅几何上的接近性并不妨碍它在实用上遥不可及，因此显得遥远。当你转身离开前门，走向未锁的后门时，你在几何上远离了门厅，但在实用上却靠近了它：“客观存在事物的客观距离与世界上手边事物的远近并不一致。” 5
  • When choosing one of two ways to achieve a certain goal, it is not always the geometrically shortest way that is pragmatically closest to the goal. If you have forgotten to bring your keys, and you are standing outside your locked front door, the geometrical proximity of the entrance hall does not prevent it from being pragmatically out of reach and, hence, remote. The moment you turn away from the front door and head for the unlocked back door, you are moving away from the entrance hall in geometrical terms, but moving closer in pragmatic terms: “The objective distances of objectively present things do not coincide with the remoteness and nearness of what is at hand within the world”.5
  • 如果道路状况良好且地势平坦，骑自行车可能很容易到达10英里外的城镇。因此，该城镇可能比几英里外的岩石山顶近得多。“一条‘客观上’很长的路，可能比一条‘客观上’短得多的路更短，而这条路或许是一条‘艰巨的路’，让人觉得无限长的路。” 6换句话说，测量可以尽可能精确，但在确定我们经验和实际交往中所体现的真正空间性时，测量结果并不相关且有用。
  • A town that is 10 miles away may be within easy reach of a bicycle ride if the roads are good and the itinerary flat. As such, the town may be considerably closer than a rocky mountaintop a couple of miles away. “An ‘objectively’ long path can be shorter than an ‘objectively’ much shorter path which is perhaps an ‘onerous one’ and strikes one as infinitely long”.6 In other words, measurements can be as exact as you like, without thereby being relevant and useful when it comes to determining genuine spatiality as manifested in our experiences and pragmatic dealings.

海德格尔的分析揭示了两种截然不同的空间概念。一方面，是欧几里得几何中精确的三维空间。另一方面，是展开的空间。在此在与实体的实际交往现成的。人们或许会倾向于认为几何测量能够客观地描述空间的本来面目，而依赖于诸如便捷性和快速性等标准的空间概念则是主观主义的，或者充其量是以人类为中心的。然而，海德格尔反对这种观点，他认为物理空间比实用空间更为根本的观点仅仅揭示了先验的形而上学承诺。真正的现实恰恰是在“此在”的“在世”中并通过其揭示的现实。根据海德格尔的说法，正是因为空间在实用的语境中对我们而言是可及的，它才可以被作为超然的科学知识的对象。在我们与现成的实体进行密切互动时，有时可能会出现对更精确测量的需求，例如在建造建筑物或桥梁，或进行土地测量时。如果我们进一步完全脱离实用主义的兴趣，那么空间就可能成为纯粹观察和理论化的对象。7然而，毫不意外的是，海德格尔声称，这种对空间几何学的专注会导致对原本既定的、实用主义意义的空间的中性化。正如海德格尔所言，空间因此“失去了其世俗性”。8关切性互动的具体语境的空间性被转化为纯粹的维度性。由此，那些唾手可得的实体失去了其独特的指涉性，世界被还原为一个由延展的事物组成的集合体。

Heidegger’s analysis reveals two very different notions of space. On the one hand, there is the exact, three-dimensional space of Euclidian geometry. On the other hand, there is space as it unfolds in Dasein’s practical dealings with entities that are ready-to-hand. One might be tempted to suggest that geometric measurements give us an objective description of space as it really is, whereas a conception of space that relies on criteria such as ease and speed of access is subjectivist or, at best, anthropocentric. Heidegger, however, resists this suggestion and argues that the idea that physical space is more fundamental than pragmatic space simply reveals prior metaphysical commitments. The really real reality is precisely the one that is disclosed in and through Dasein’s being-in-the-world. It is, according to Heidegger, precisely because space is accessible to us in a pragmatic context that it can be made the object of detached, scientific knowledge. In our concernful dealings with entities that are ready-to-hand, a need for more exact measurements may sometimes arise, for example, in the construction of buildings or bridges, or in the surveying of land. If one goes on to abstract completely from pragmatic interests, then space can become the object of mere observation and theorising.7 Unsurprisingly, however, Heidegger claims that such an exclusive focus on the geometry of space involves a neutralisation of the originally given, pragmatically significant space. As Heidegger puts it, space thereby becomes “deprived of its worldliness”.8 The spatiality of the concrete context of concernful dealings is transformed into a pure dimensionality. Thereby, entities that are ready-to-hand lose their peculiar referential character, and the world is reduced to a conglomerate of extended things.

当我们讨论我们与器具的实用性处理的空间性时，有一个东西一直被预设，但没有被明确主题化——那就是此在的具身化。然而，在《存在与时间》中，海德格尔在一个地方明确提到了身体。这是在第23节，他指出此在自身的空间性与其“肉体性”相联系。然而，他接着补充说，身体“包含着它自己的问题，在此不予讨论”。9这种对身体的沉默令人费解，尤其是考虑到海德格尔自己的术语——例如，上手状态和现成状态之间的区别——不断让人注意到此在是具身化的（例如，有手）。此外，海德格尔对空间令人关切的揭示的论述，在某种程度上从某种意义上说，一切都与身体有关。某个地方或实体的远近，恰恰与其可用性、到达的难易程度等等有关。所有这些无疑都指向了工作、把握、行走——简而言之，体现——的主体。

When discussing the spatiality of our pragmatic dealing with equipment, there is something that has constantly been presupposed without being explicitly thematised – namely, Dasein’s embodiment. There is, however, one place in Being and Time where Heidegger explicitly mentions the body. This is in section 23, where he states that Dasein’s own spatiality is connected to its “corporeality”. He goes on to add, however, that the body “contains a problematic of its own not to be discussed here”.9 This silence regarding the body is puzzling, especially considering how Heidegger’s own terminology – for example, the distinction between the ready-to-hand and the present-at-hand – draws constant attention to the fact that Dasein is embodied (e.g., has hands). Moreover, Heidegger’s account of the concernful disclosure of space has, in a sense, been all about the body. The closeness or remoteness of some place or entity has precisely to do with its availability for use, the ease (or otherwise) with which it may be reached, and so on. All of this surely refers us to the working, grasping, walking – in short, embodied – subject.

有人或许会反驳说，此在具身性是显而易见且不证自明的，因此，明确的分析是多余的。但这样的回答无疑过于肤浅。正如海德格尔本人在《存在与时间》第一部分中所强调的那样，在哲学中“诉诸自明性[……]是一种值得怀疑的做法”。10就此在的具身性而言，情况也是如此，因为对此进行深入分析实际上可以决定性地加深我们对心灵与世界关系的理解，而这正是其他现象学家，包括胡塞尔、萨特和梅洛-庞蒂所主张的。

It might be objected that it is both obvious and self-evident that Dasein is embodied, and that an explicit analysis, therefore, is superfluous. But surely such a reply is too facile. As Heidegger himself emphasises in the first section of Being and Time, in philosophy “the appeal to self-evidence [. . .] is a dubious procedure”.10 This is also the case when it comes to Dasein’s embodiment, since an in-depth analysis hereof can in fact add decisively to our understanding of the mind–world relation, which is precisely what other phenomenologists, including Husserl, Sartre, and Merleau-Ponty, would argue.

活生生的身体

THE LIVED BODY

在特定的理论框架下，身体首先是世界中的一个空间客体，这似乎是显而易见的。正如我们能够感知一串葡萄或一团篝火一样，我们能够看到、触摸和闻到身体。这也是现象学家的观点吗？对身体的现象学研究应该将身体作为一种现象来研究。但是，当我们欣赏一幅画或使用吸尘器时，身体究竟是如何被赋予的？它是如何呈现的？它是否包含在我们感知到的客体之中？我是否意识到自己的身体是空间中的一个感知客体？正如胡塞尔、梅洛-庞蒂和萨特所坚持的那样，身体并非众多客体中的一个。它的呈现方式实际上与普通客体截然不同。我可以接近和远离空间客体，而身体始终存在，因为它使我能够采用一种视角来看待世界。事实上，身体首先是这种看待世界的视角，因此，它最初并非我所采用视角的对象。否则，就等于开启了无限倒退。11萨特甚至写道，活着的身体之所以无形地存在，正是因为它是存在地活着，而非被知晓。12

Given a certain theoretical framework, it might seem obvious that the body is first and foremost a spatial object in the world. Just as we can perceive a bunch of grapes or a bonfire, we can see, touch, and smell the body. Is this also the view of phenomenologists? A phenomenological investigation of the body should presumably focus on the body as a phenomenon. But how exactly is the body given when we admire a painting or use the vacuum cleaner? How is it present? Is it among the perceptually available objects? Am I aware of my own body as a perceptual object in space? As Husserl, Merleau-Ponty, and Sartre all insist, the body is not simply one object among many. Its mode of appearance is in fact quite different from ordinary objects. Whereas I can approach and remove myself from spatial objects, the body is always present as that which makes it possible for me to adopt a perspective on the world. Indeed, the body is first and foremost this perspective on the world, and, therefore, not originally an object that I take a perspective on. To claim otherwise is to commence an infinite regress.11 Sartre even writes that the lived body is invisibly present, precisely because it is existentially lived rather than known.12

正常情况下，我不需要通过视觉感知手的位置就能知道它在哪里。当我伸手去拿球拍时，我不需要先去找那只手。我不需要寻找它，因为它一直都在我身边。我也不需要看自己，就能知道自己是坐着还是躺着，或者我的腿是否交叉着。

Under normal circumstances, I do not need to perceive the hand visually in order to know where it is located. When I reach for the racket, I do not first have to search for the hand. I do not need to look for it, since it is always with me. I also don’t need to look at myself to find out if I’m sitting up or lying down, or if my legs are crossed or not.

让我们设想这样一种情形：我们坐在餐厅里。我想开始用餐，所以我需要拿起刀叉。但我该怎么做呢？为了拿起刀叉，我需要知道它们相对于我自己的位置。也就是说，我对刀叉的感知必须包含一些关于我自己位置的信息，否则我将无法据此采取行动。在餐桌上，感知到的刀叉在我左边，感知到的刀在我右边，而感知到的盘子和酒杯在我前面。因此，身体的特征在于，它存在于每一次感知体验中，作为体验的零点，即绝对的“此处”，所有出现的物体都以此为参照。身体的“此处”并非众多点中的一个，而是使其他坐标变得有意义的锚点。最初——即在反思之前——身体并非以透视的方式被赋予，我自身也并非作为存在于空间客体中或作为空间客体而被赋予。否则，我们就误解了我们身体存在的真实本质：

Let us consider a situation, where we are sitting in a restaurant. I wish to begin to eat, and so I need to pick up the fork and knife. But how can I do that? In order to pick up either, I need to know their position in relation to myself. That is, my perception of the fork and knife must contain some information about my own location, otherwise I would not be able to act on it. On the dinner table, the perceived fork is to the left (of me), the perceived knife is to the right (of me), and the perceived plate and wineglass in front (of me). The body is, consequently, characterised by being present in every perceptual experience as the experiential zero-point, the absolute “here” in relation to which every appearing object is oriented. The bodily “here” is not one point among many, but the anchor that makes other coordinates meaningful. Originally – i.e., pre-reflectively – the body is not given perspectivally, and I am not given to myself as existing in or as a spatial object. To claim otherwise is to misunderstand the true nature of our bodily existence:

身体及其与意识的关系问题常常被以下事实所掩盖：身体从一开始就被设定为某种拥有自身规律并可从外部定义的事物，而意识则通过其特有的内在直觉而达到。事实上，如果我在通过一系列反思活动，在其绝对内在性中把握了“我的”意识之后，试图将其与某个由神经系统、大脑、腺体、消化器官、呼吸器官和循环器官组成的生物体相结合，而这些器官的物质本身可以被化学分析为氢原子、碳原子、氮原子、磷原子等，那么我将面临难以克服的困难。但这些困难都源于这样一个事实：我试图将我的意识与他人的身体而非我的身体相结合。因为我刚才描述的身体并非我本人的身体。13

The problem of the body and its relations with consciousness is often obscured by the fact that while the body is from the start posited as a certain thing having its own laws and capable of being defined from outside, consciousness is then reached by the type of inner intuition which is peculiar to it. Actually if after grasping “my” consciousness in its absolute interiority and by a series of reflective acts, I then seek to unite it with a certain living object composed of a nervous system, a brain, glands, digestive, respiratory, and circulatory organs whose very matter is capable of being analyzed chemically into atoms of hydrogen, carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, etc., then I am going to encounter insurmountable difficulties. But these difficulties all stem from the fact that I try to unite my consciousness not with my body but with the body of others. For the body which I have just described is not my body such as it is for me.13

作为一个体验的、具身的主体，我是一个参考点，我的所有感知对象，无论远近、左或右、上或下，都与此有着独特的联系：

As an experiencing, embodied subject, I am the point of reference in relation to which all of my perceptual objects, be they near or far, left or right, up or down, are uniquely related:

因此，周围世界的所有事物都具有朝向身体的方向[……]。“远”是指离我远，离我的身体远；“向右”指的是我身体的右侧，例如，我的右手。[……]万物在我之上，也在我对面；它们都在“那里”——除了一个，也是唯一一个，那就是身体，它始终在“这里” 。14

It is thus that all things of the surrounding world possess an orientation to the Body [. . .]. The “far” is far from me, from my Body; the “to the right” refers back to the right side of my Body, e.g., to my right hand. [. . .] I have all things over and against me; they are all “there” – with the exception of one and only one, namely the Body, which is always “here”.14

我是中心，（自我中心的）空间围绕着它展开，并相对于它展开，这也是为什么胡塞尔写道，每一个世界经验都是由我们的具身化。15之所以如此，不仅是因为身体充当着稳定的方向中心，还因为它的移动性。我们用位于头部的可转动的眼睛来观察，而头部又与身体相连，身体可以从一处移动至另一处；从这个意义上讲，固定的视角只是移动视角的极限情况。我们所看到、听到和触觉、味觉和嗅觉是由我们的行为和能力塑造的。锤子是我可以抓着用的东西。挡路的木头是我可以爬过去或坐在上面休息的东西。冰冻的湖面是我可以跨过的。我们可以立即判断一个物体是否触手可及，门口是否足够大，无需弯腰就能穿过，椅子的高度是否合适，等等。这种体验与身体相关，它不是特定几何尺寸的体验，而是对距离和大小与我们自身体态是否合适的评估。

I am the centre around which and in relation to which (egocentric) space unfolds itself, which is also why Husserl writes that every world-experience is enabled by our embodiment.15 This is so, not only because the body functions as a stable centre of orientation, but also because of its mobility. We see with mobile eyes that are set in a head that can turn and which is attached to a body that can move from place to place; a stationary point of view is to that extent only the limiting case of a mobile point of view. What we see and hear and touch and taste and smell is shaped by what we do, and what we are capable of doing. A hammer is something I can grab and use. A log blocking the road is something I can climb over or sit on to rest. A frozen lake is something I can cross. We can instantly see if an object is within reach, if a doorway is big enough to walk through without having to bend down, if a chair is the right height to sit on, etc. This experience is body-related, it is not an experience of specific geometric measurements, but an assessment of whether the distance and size is appropriate vis-à-vis our own embodiment.

在日常经验中，感知与运动是统一的。当我触摸海绵表面时，海绵与手指运动的体验结合在一起。当我观察场景中舞者的动作时，舞者与我头部运动的体验结合在一起。这种胡塞尔式的论证思路在梅洛-庞蒂和萨特的著作中也能找到。梅洛-庞蒂写道，当我感知世界时，身体同时被揭示为世界中心未被感知的术语，所有物体都将其指向……脸。16我不是从远处观察世界，而是置身于世界的中心，世界根据我们身体栖居的方式展现自身。萨特谈到空间是如何通过使用指涉构建的，其中单个物体的位置和方向与一个行动主体相联系。被感知的事物被感知为近处或远处，是可以接近和探索的事物。刀子放在桌子上意味着我可以伸手抓住它。身体在每一个感知和每一个行动中都发挥作用。它构成了我们的视角和出发点。17

In ordinary experience, perception and movement are united. When I touch the surface of a sponge, the sponge is given in conjunction with an experience of the movement of the finger. When I observe the movement of the dancer on the scene, the dancer is given in conjunction with the experience of the movement of my head. This Husserlian line of argument can also be found in Merleau-Ponty and Sartre. Merleau-Ponty writes that when I perceive the world, the body is simultaneously revealed as the unperceived term in the centre of the world toward which all objects turn their face.16 I do not observe the world from a distance, but I am placed right in its middle, and the world reveals itself according to our bodily ways of inhabiting it. Sartre speaks of how space is structured by references of use where the position and orientation of the individual objects are connected to an acting subject. That which is perceived is perceived as nearby or further away, as something that can be approached and explored. That the knife is lying there on the table means that I can reach and grasp it. The body is operative in every perception and in every action. It constitutes our point of view and our point of departure.17

知觉场指的是一个由该参照客观定义的中心，它位于围绕它定向的场中。只是我们并不将这个中心视为所考虑的知觉场的结构；我们就是中心。 [...]因此，我的在世存在，仅仅因为它实现了一个世界，就使它所实现的世界将自己指示为在世界中的存在。情况不可能不是这样，因为我的存在除了身处世界中之外，没有其他方式与世界接触。我不可能实现一个我不在其中的世界，而这个世界对我来说将是一个纯粹的审视沉思的对象。[...]因此，说我已进入世界，“来到世界”，或者说有一个世界，或者说我有一个身体，都是一回事。18

[T]he perceptive field refers to a center objectively defined by that reference and located in the very field which is oriented around it. only we do not see this center as the structure of the perceptive field considered; we are the center. [. . .] Thus my being-in-the-world, by the sole fact that it realizes a world, causes itself to be indicated to itself as a being-in-the-midst-of-the-world by the world which it realizes. The case could not be otherwise, for my being has no other way of entering into contact with the world except to be in the world. It would be impossible for me to realize a world in which I was not and which would be for me a pure object of a surveying contemplation. [. . .] Thus to say that I have entered into the world, “come to the world”, or that there is a world, or that I have a body is one and the same thing.18

当论证身体在不同形式的意向性——例如，当我们声称感知本质上是一种具身活动时——重要的并非主体只有在拥有身体的情况下才能感知物体并使用工具，而是主体只有在拥有身体的情况下才能做到这一点，即具身的主观性。或者换句话说，我们必须认识到，身体上的“我能”构成了意向性的基本形式。

When arguing that the body plays a decisive role in different forms of intentionality – when claiming that perception, for instance, is an essentially embodied activity – the important point is not that the subject can only perceive objects and employ tools if it has a body, but, rather, that it can only do so if it is a body, i.e., an embodied subjectivity. Or to put it differently, what has to be recognised is that the bodily “I can” constitutes a fundamental form of intentionality.

正如萨特所指出的，我们不应该让我们对身体的研究受外部生理视角的引导，这种视角最终源于对尸体的解剖学研究。19胡塞尔已经提出的一个核心区别是：（a）我们最初的非主题性的、前反思性的身体意识，它伴随并制约着每一次空间体验；以及（b）随之而来的身体作为客体的主题体验。有必要区分主观体验中的身体，以及作为客体的身体。胡塞尔运用了莱布（Leib ）和科尔珀（Körper）的概念，而梅洛-庞蒂后来区分了“本体”（corps propre）和“客体”（corps objectif）。正如胡塞尔所坚持的，后一种身体意识形式依赖于前一种：

As Sartre points out, we should not let our investigation of the body be led by an external physiological perspective which ultimately has its origin in the anatomical study of the corpse.19 A central distinction, already introduced by Husserl, is here the one between (a) our original unthematic, pre-reflectively lived body-awareness that accompanies and conditions every spatial experience, and (b) the subsequent thematic experience of the body as an object. It is necessary to distinguish the body as it is subjectively lived through, and the body as an object among others. Whereas Husserl employs the concepts of Leib and Körper, Merleau-Ponty would later distinguish between corps propre and corps objectif. As Husserl insists, the latter form of body-awareness depends upon the former:

这里还必须注意，在所有事物的体验中，生命体都是作为一个有功能的生命体（因此不仅仅是一个事物）而被共同体验的，并且当生命体本身作为一个事物被体验时，它是以双重方式被体验的——即，准确地说，作为一个被体验的事物和作为一个有功能的生命体合二为一。20

Here it must also be noted that in all experience of things, the lived body is co-experienced as a functioning lived body (thus not as a mere thing), and that when it itself is experienced as a thing, it is experienced in a double way—i.e., precisely as an experienced thing and as a functioning lived body together in one.20

显然，身体可以探索自身。它可以将自身（或他人的身体）作为探索的对象。这在生理学或神经学中很常见。但这种将身体作为客体的研究既不详尽，也未能揭示身体最根本的本质。将身体构建为客体并非由脱离肉体的主体进行的活动。它是一种由具身主体实现的自我客体化。活生生的身体先于被感知的身体。起初，我对自己的身体没有任何意识。我不是在感知它，而是我就是它。21

Obviously, the body can explore itself. It can take itself (or the body of another) as an object of exploration. This is what typically happens in physiology or neurology. But such an investigation of the body as an object is neither exhaustive, nor does it disclose the most fundamental nature of the body. The constitution of the body as an object is not an activity that is carried out by a disincarnate subject. It is a self-objectification effectuated by an embodied subject. The lived body precedes the perceived body. Originally, I do not have any consciousness of my body. I am not perceiving it, I am it.21

客体身体捕捉的是观察者如何从观察者的角度来理解身体，观察者可能是科学家、医生，甚至是具身主体本身，而主观身体的概念则捕捉的是身体如何从具身主体的角度来体验。第一人称视角。身体作为主体与身体作为客体之间的区别是一种现象学区别。其核心并非指我们每个人都拥有两个不同的身体，而是指我们能够以不同的方式体验和理解同一个身体。

Whereas the body as object captures how the body is apprehended from an observer’s point of view, where the observer might be a scientist, a physician, or even the embodied subject herself, the notion of a subjective body captures the way the body is lived through from an embodied first-person perspective. The distinction between the body as subject and the body as object is a phenomenological distinction. The idea is not that we each have two different bodies, but rather that we can experience and understand the same body in different ways.

但为什么触觉或视觉探索的身体仍然可以被体验为我自身身体的外在性呢？胡塞尔和梅洛-庞蒂都强调了他们所谓的双重感觉或双重触碰。当我的左手触碰我的右手时，触碰的左手会感受到被触碰的右手的表面。但被触碰的右手并非仅仅作为一个简单的物体存在，因为它感觉触摸本身。22此外，触摸者和被触摸者之间的关系是可逆的，因为右手也可以触摸左手。正是这种可逆性表明身体的内在性和外在性是同一性的不同表现形式。23因此，双重触摸现象为我们呈现了一个模棱两可的场景，其中手在触摸者和被触摸的两个角色之间交替。也就是说，双重感觉现象为我们提供了身体双重性质的体验。有时，用“Leibkörper”这个说法来表示这种身体的自我体验。

But why is it that the tactually or visually explored body can still be experienced as the exteriority of my own body? This is where both Husserl and Merleau-Ponty highlight the importance of what they call double-sensation or double-touch. When my left hand touches my right hand, the left touching hand feels the surface of the right touched hand. But the touched right hand is not simply given as a mere object, since it feels the touch itself.22 Moreover, the relation between the touching and the touched is reversible, since the right hand can also touch the left hand. It is this reversibility that demonstrates that the bodily interiority and exteriority are different manifestations of the same.23 The phenomenon of double-touch consequently presents us with an ambiguous setting in which the hand alternates between two roles, that of touching and that of being touched. That is, the phenomenon of double-sensation provides us with an experience of the dual nature of the body. Sometimes, the locution Leibkörper is used to designate that kind of bodily self-experience.

通常情况下，我们的身体在达到其有意目标的过程中往往会自我消解。我们通常不会以明确的意识方式监控自己的动作。这很幸运，因为如果我们像专注地觉察物体一样觉察身体动作，我们的身体就会对我们的意识提出如此高的要求，以至于会干扰我们的日常生活。当我在笔记本电脑上写作时，我的动作并非作为有意为之的对象。我的四肢不会争夺我的注意力。如果是这样，我就无法高效地写作。当然，如果出现问题，情况可能会发生变化。不妨考虑一下德鲁·莱德讨论过的一个案例。想象一下你正在打网球。你的注意力集中在高速飞向你的球上，同时也关注着对手的位置。你的身体绷紧，准备以精湛的扣杀回击，但突然间，你感到一阵尖锐而强烈的手臂疼痛。你失去了绝杀的机会，现在疼痛需要你全部的注意力。不管你愿意与否，它都会吸引你的注意力。事实上，没有什么比疼痛更能让我们想起我们的肉体（我们的脆弱性和必死性）。24更一般地说，身体以一种基本的方式存在，我们通常只在我们与世界习惯性的顺畅互动受到干扰时才会注意到它，无论是通过自愿的反思（无论是哲学的还是镜像的），还是通过疾病、身体需要、疲惫或疼痛强加给我们的反思。就像生活中的许多其他事情一样，往往是剥夺让我们认识到那些我们认为理所当然的事情的重要性。当它不再顺利运作时，我们才意识到身体的基本作用。

Normally, our body tends to efface itself on its way to its intentional goal. We do not normally monitor our movements in an explicitly conscious manner. This is fortunate, for had we been aware of our bodily movements in the same way in which we are attentively aware of objects, our body would have made such high demands on our consciousness that it would have interfered with our daily life. When I write on my laptop, my movements are not given as intentional objects. My limbs do not compete for my attention. Had that been the case, I would not have been able to write efficiently. But, of course, things might change if something goes wrong. Consider a case discussed by Drew Leder. Imagine that you are playing tennis. Your attention is directed at the ball, which is heading towards you with high speed, as well as on the position of your opponent. Your body tightens in order to return the ball in a masterful smash, but suddenly you feel a sharp and intense pain in your arm. Your smashing opportunity is lost, and the pain is now demanding all your attention. It attracts your attention whether you want it to or not. Indeed, there might be nothing that reminds us as much of our embodiment (our vulnerability and mortality) as pain.24 More generally speaking, the body is present in such a fundamental manner that we normally only notice it when our habitual and smooth interaction with the world is disturbed, be it by voluntary reflections (be they philosophical or specular), or by reflections that are forced upon us by sickness, bodily needs, exhaustion, or pain. As with so many other things in life, it is often deprivation that teaches us about the importance of that which we take for granted. It is when it no longer functions smoothly that we realise the fundamental role of the body.

这种具身化的概念绝不会让我们将身体视为静止的，仿佛它拥有一套固定的技能和能力。身体不仅可以通过习得新的技能和习惯来扩展其感觉运动能力，甚至可以通过融入人造器官和其周围环境的某些部分来扩展其能力。梅洛-庞蒂提到的一个经典案例是关于盲人和他的手杖的。25当盲人用手杖探索地面时，他感觉不到手中的手杖，而是前方的地面。这仿佛是他感知身体的边界已经扩展，不再止步于皮肤。

Nothing in this conception of embodiment should lead us to think of the body as something static, as if it has a fixed set of skills and abilities. Not only can the body expand its sensorimotor repertoire by acquiring new skills and habits, it can even extend its capacities by incorporating artificial organs and parts of its environment. A classical case mentioned by Merleau-Ponty concerns the blind man and his cane.25 When exploring the ground with the cane, the man does not feel the cane in his hand, but the ground in front of him. It is as if the borders of his sensing body have expanded and no longer stop at the skin.

现象学对身体的研究显然并非众多分析中的一种。现象学在研究不同种类的客体时，并非偶然发现了身体，然后才对其进行进一步的研究。相反，胡塞尔和法国现象学家都赋予身体一种特殊的地位，因为它被认为深深地与我们与世界的关系、我们与他人的关系以及我们自身的关系息息相关。自我关系。

The phenomenological investigation of the body is clearly not simply one analysis among many. It is not as if phenomenology, in its investigation of different kinds of objects, also stumbled upon the body and then proceeded to investigate it further. On the contrary, both Husserl and the French phenomenologists grant the body a special status, since it is taken to be deeply implicated in our relation to the world, in our relation to others, and in our self-relation.

现象学家并非为经典的身心问题提供解决方案：身体如何与心灵产生因果互动？相反，他们试图理解我们对世界的体验、对自我的体验以及对他人的体验在多大程度上是由我们的身体所塑造和影响的。但通过这种关注点的转变，他们也重新思考并质疑了一些定义身心区别的理论。首先是心身问题。“具身”的概念，即具身心灵或心智体的概念，旨在取代通常的“心智”和“身体”的概念，后者被认为是衍生和抽象的概念。换句话说，我们的身体体验不能被简单地归类为主观或客观、内在或外在、物理或心理。胡塞尔认为身体“同时是空间的外在性和主观的内在性”，而梅洛-庞蒂则探讨了身体的模糊性，并认为身体存在是超越单纯生理和心理的第三范畴。

Phenomenologists do not offer a solution to the classical mind– body problem: How does the body interact causally with the mind? Rather, they seek to understand to what extent our experience of the world, our experience of self, and our experience of others are formed by and influenced by our embodiment. But through this change of focus, they also rethink and question some of the distinctions that define the mind–body problem in the first place. The notion of embodiment, the notion of an embodied mind or a minded body, is meant to replace the ordinary notions of mind and body, both of which are considered derivations and abstractions. To put it differently, our bodily experience cannot neatly be categorised as either subjective or objective, inner or outer, physical or psychical. Whereas Husserl writes that the body is “simultaneously a spatial externality and a subjective internality”,26 Merleau-Ponty speaks of the ambiguous nature of the body and argues that bodily existence is a third category beyond the merely physiological and the merely psychological.27

认真对待具身性，就意味着在多个方面挑战笛卡尔的心灵观。具身性意味着出生和死亡。出生并非一个人自身的根基，而是被置于自然和文化之中。出生意味着拥有一种并非由自己选择的生理机能。出生意味着置身于一个并非由自己建立的历史和社会背景之中。最终，生与死的问题扩大了研究的范围。它们唤起人们对……的作用的关注。历史性、生殖性和性。28的确，具身性不仅仅是生物学上的既定事实，它也是社会文化分析的一个范畴。为了更全面地理解具身心智，我们不能仅仅局限于感知和行动，还必须考虑社会性。

To take embodiment seriously is to contest a Cartesian view of the mind in more than one way. Embodiment entails birth and death. To be born is not to be one’s own foundation, but to be situated in both nature and culture. It is to possess a physiology that one did not choose. It is to find oneself in a historical and sociological context that one did not establish. Ultimately, the issues of birth and death enlarge the scope of the investigation. They call attention to the role of historicity, generativity, and sexuality.28 Indeed, rather than being simply a biological given, embodiment is also a category of sociocultural analysis. To gain a more comprehensive understanding of the embodied mind, one cannot just focus narrowly on perception and action, one also has to consider sociality.

笔记
